Title: Views You Can Use: War In Ferguson
Author: Rachel Brody
ArticleText:
Tension is mounting in Ferguson, Missouri, where an unarmed black man was shot and killed by police on Saturday. The death of 18-year-old Michael Brown has sparked outrage in the St. Louis suburb, prompting protests, looting and violence.

Early Wednesday morning, an armed man was shot and critically wounded by police near the site of the demonstrations. Local police have also used tear gas and rubber bullets against protesters, and the Federal Aviation Administration has issued a no-fly zone over Ferguson, after police reported gunfire aimed at their helicopters.

President Barack Obama released a statement Tuesday, calling for an end to the violence in Ferguson. “We should comfort each other and talk with one another in a way that heals,” said Obama, “not in a way that wounds.”

While Brown’s family members have also urged peace, they and the NAACP are calling on officials to {release the name of the policeman}<hyperlink=” http://www.usnews.com/news/articles/2014/08/12/naacp-to-cops-identify-michael-brown-shooter”> (now on paid leave) who shot Michael. Police Chief Thomas Jackson reneged Tuesday on a plan to make the officer’s name public, saying the department received online death threats. “The situation, the social media situation is so volatile that it’s probably going to be delayed for a little while,” Jackson {told NBC}<hyperlink=” http://www.nbcnews.com/storyline/michael-brown-shooting/michael-brown-protesters-cops-face-ferguson-missouri-n179346”>.

Much of the tension surrounding Brown’s death is due to the conflicting accounts from police and eyewitnesses. Police say Brown assaulted an officer and a struggle for the officer’s weapon ensued; police acknowledge a shot was fired in the officers' car but offered no details on what followed, despite saying Brown was “shot more than just a couple of times.”

But Dorian Johnson, a friend who was walking with Brown, say things happened differently. After telling the boys to get off the street and onto the sidewalk, the officer opened his squad car door, where it “ricocheted” off the pair, angering the policeman. The officer then reached out from his squad car, grabbing Brown by the neck and then arm to pull him inside. Johnson says the officer drew his weapon in the car, saying he would shoot Brown and then did. Brown and Johnson then fled, the officer shot again, and Brown turned around with his hands overhead. The police then fired “several more shots,” says Johnson, “and my friend died.”

“Michael Brown was black and tall,” wrote the {New Yorker’s Amy Davidson}<hyperlink=” http://www.newyorker.com/news/amy-davidson/michael-brown-die-ferguson”>. “[W]as it his body that the police officer thought was dangerous enough?” Davidson says Brown’s shooting echoes the death of another black teen, Trayvon Martin, who was shot and killed by George Zimmerman, who then pleaded self-defense. “One way or the other, this happens too often to young men who look like Brown, or like Trayvon Martin, or, as President Obama once put it, like a son he might have had,” wrote Davidson.

{Deadspin’s Greg Howard}<hyperlink=” http://theconcourse.deadspin.com/america-is-not-for-black-people-1620169913”> said Brown’s death serves as a sobering reminder that “The United States of America is not for black people." Police officers are given the power and the tools — guns, armor, planes, military-like training — to “patrol” America’s streets, argues Howard.

If officers are soldiers, it follows that the neighborhoods they patrol are battlefields. And if they're working battlefields, it follows that the population is the enemy. And because of correlations, rooted in historical injustice, between crime and income and income and race, the enemy population will consist largely of people of color, and especially of black men.

The Justice Department has called on the FBI to launch an independent investigation of the shooting, but the real problem is an “insidious cycle” embedded within the legal system itself, said {CNN’s Mark O’Mara}<hyperlink=” http://www.cnn.com/2014/08/13/opinion/omara-michael-brown-police-shooting-racial-injustice/”>. “If you want to say the cop's at fault because he's the adult with training, you are right. And if you want to say the young man is at fault for disrespect or mistrust of a cop's authority, you are right,” O’Mara argued. Both sides are stuck firmly in their camps, much to the detriment of relations between minorities and the police.

Regardless, said O’Mara, the responsibility lies with police to make this first step toward bettering the system: “Police officers are in the position of authority, and they have the power to send a message that when they serve a community, they serve all the people of the community equally, regardless of race.”
TheShitBetween: Conflicting reports over the death of a young black man have ignited outrage in Missouri.
Notes: “If officers” quote from link, but larger and slightly grey

Title: Ferguson Police Chief Identifies Michael Brown Shooter
Author: Andrew Soergel
ArticleText:
The police department in Ferguson, Missouri, has identified Darren Wilson as the officer involved in the fatal shooting of unarmed teenager Michael Brown.

Police had been withholding Wilson’s name in fear of retaliation against him. On Friday, Ferguson Police Chief Thomas Jackson named Wilson while speaking outside of a QuikTrip gas station that had been burned to the ground during riots this week.

Wilson was reportedly responding to a sick call before encountering Brown. Jackson alluded to a “strong-armed robbery” that took place that day, but did not immediately connect Brown to the incident. 

A {police report}<hyperlink=”http://i2.cdn.turner.com/cnn/2014/images/08/15/ferguson.police.documents.pdf”> released later Friday morning named Brown as a suspect in a convenience store robbery that occurred on Saturday, the day he was shot, according to {CNN}<hyperlink=”http://www.cnn.com/2014/08/15/us/missouri-teen-shooting/index.html”>.

But Wilson was reportedly unaware that Brown was a robbery suspect at the time, Jackson said, according to {The Associated Press}<hyperlink=”http://www.usnews.com/news/us/articles/2014/08/15/turmoil-tear-gas-give-way-to-hope-in-ferguson”>.

Brown and another person were stopped "because they were walking down the middle of the street blocking traffic," Jackson said.

Dorian Johnson, who said he was with Brown when the teenager first encountered Wilson, is also named as a suspect, according to the report. A box of Swisher Sweets cigars valued at $48.99 was reportedly stolen from the convenience store, according to {Fox News}<hyperlink=”http://www.foxnews.com/us/2014/08/15/ferguson-police-say-michael-brown-fit-description-strong-arm-robbery-suspect.html”> and {The Associated Press}<hyperlink=”http://www.usnews.com/news/us/articles/2014/08/15/turmoil-tear-gas-give-way-to-hope-in-ferguson?src=usn_tw”>.

Images from the convenience store's security cameras were released Friday that show a confrontation in the store between two men, one larger than the other. The police documents indicate that Brown matched the description of the robbery suspect when Wilson confronted him Aug. 9.

[tweetbegin 500311153583853570 tweetend]"It still doesn't justify shooting him when he puts his hands up," said Bernard Ewing, Brown's uncle, noting Johnson's report that Brown had his hands raised over his head during the shooting. 

Jackson said Wilson had already shot Brown by the time a second police officer arrived minutes later.

Wilson’s identification comes a day after President Barack Obama called for more transparency from law enforcement following a spate of heated protests in Ferguson.
 “Put simply, we all need to hold ourselves to a high standard, particularly those in positions of authority,” 

Obama said Thursday from Martha’s Vineyard in Massachusetts. “When something like this happens, the local authorities, including the police, have a responsibility to be open and transparent about how they are investigating that death and how they are protecting the people in their communities."
Obama said Thursday that the FBI and the Department of Justice would both investigate the circumstances behind Brown’s death. Local law enforcement officers have been criticized for using excessive force – involving rubber bullets, tear gas and smoke bombs – in responding to protests, according to {Fox News}<hyperlink=”http://www.foxnews.com/us/2014/08/14/police-clash-with-michael-brown-shooting-protesters-in-ferguson-two-reporters.html”> and {The Christian Science Monitor}<hyperlink=”http://www.csmonitor.com/USA/Latest-News-Wires/2014/0814/Police-in-Ferguson-Mo.-break-up-protests-with-tear-gas-again”>.

Mingling with Ferguson protesters Thursday was Missouri State Highway Patrol Capt. Ronald S. Johnson, who was that day placed in charge of maintaining peace in Ferguson by Missouri Democratic Gov. Jay Nixon.

“We are going to have a different approach and have the approach that we’re in this together,” Johnson said Thursday, according to CNN and {PIX11}<hyperlink=”http://pix11.com/2014/08/14/governor-of-missouri-puts-state-troopers-in-charge/”>.

[tweetbegin 500277751270879232 tweetend] Johnson’s first day in charge of Ferguson security was markedly different from the days prior. SWAT gear and tear gas were cast aside as Johnson hugged, kissed and laughed with protesters, according to Elahe Izadi and Wesley Lowery of {The Washington Post}<hyperlink=”https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/post-nation/wp/2014/08/14/meet-the-missouri-highway-state-patrol-captain-who-is-taking-over-in-ferguson/”>. Lowery was one of two journalists detained by police Wednesday inside a McDonald's restaurant.

Johnson's treatment of protesters seemed to elicit a calmer response from citizens.

“When I see a young lady cry because of fear of this uniform, that’s a problem,” Johnson said Thursday, according to the Post. “I’m not afraid to be in this crowd.”

Several officers were also seen mingling among the protesters, according to {Reuters}<hyperlink=”http://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-missouri-shooting-idUSKBN0GF0LP20140815”>.

Nixon and Johnson held a press conference Friday asking for civility and cooperation as the Brown investigation unfolds.

"Nothing should deter figuring out how and why Michael Brown was killed," Nixon said. "There are a lot of steps between now and when justice is served. There are going to be a lot of other bounces along the way. And there will be a lot of tension at various times."
"In our anger, we have to make sure that we don't burn down our own houses and we don't go down there and vandalize our own buildings," Johnson said, referring to looting and vandalism that has marked some of the past week's protests. "That does not prove a point. That does not solve the issue."

The new head of the Ferguson response is marching WITH the protesters and suddenly military weapons aren't needed. {pic.twitter.com/j19eYsMWGh }<hyperlink=" https://twitter.com/JRehling/status/500062107971231744/photo/1">
 
— JRehling (@JRehling) {August 14, 2014}<hyperlink=" https://twitter.com/JRehling/statuses/500062107971231744">

Conflicts in Ferguson this week have highlighted the suburb's bubbling racial tension. African-Americans make up two-thirds of the town’s 21,000 citizens, according to Reuters. But they reportedly account for nine out of 10 traffic stops in the area, according to {USA Today}<hyperlink=”http://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2014/08/14/antonio-french-alderman-arrest-ferguson-missouri/14042391/”>.

Johnson is African-American. But only three of Ferguson's 53 police officers are black, according to Reuters.

“This is not a black and white issue, because we all have sons and daughters,” Johnson said. “It’s time to stop saying it’s an old wound and close it for good.”

Accounts of events leading up to Brown’s death have varied. Brown, 18, was reportedly walking home from a convenience store Saturday when he was shot, according to {The New York Times}<hyperlink=”http://www.nytimes.com/2014/08/16/us/darren-wilson-identified-as-officer-in-fatal-shooting-in-ferguson-missouri.html”>.

Police claim there was a struggle between Brown and Wilson. But witnesses said Brown was retreating with raised hands as he was fired upon, according to {The Los Angeles Times}<hyperlink=”http://www.latimes.com/nation/nationnow/la-na-nn-fergsuon-shooting-police-name-20140815-story.html”>.
TheShitBetween: The officer who fatally shot the unarmed 18-year-old is a six-year police veteran.
Notes: Again, slightly larger grey quote, from link (but this time with hyperlink text), and same gallery. Do I include pictures attached to twitter links?

Title: Man Killed by Police Officers 4 Miles From Ferguson
Author: Andrew Soergel
ArticleText:
A 23-year-old robbery suspect was shot and killed by police officers north of St. Louis Tuesday, about four miles from the tumultuous Ferguson, Missouri.

“The suspect, who right now is described as a 23-year-old African-American, was acting erratically – walking back and forth up and down the street,” St. Louis Police Chief Sam Dotson said, according to. “As officers arrived, the suspect turned toward the officers and started to walk toward them clutching his waistband. He then pulled out a knife … and told the officers, ‘Shoot me now. Kill me now.”

The man was accused of taking two energy drinks and a package of pastries from a store without paying before encountering St. Louis police officers, according to {ABC News}<hyperlink=” http://abcnews.go.com/US/ferguson-chants-heard-st-louis-cops-shoot-suspect/story?id=25041218”>. Dotson said officers repeatedly told the man to put his knife down as he approached. The suspect reportedly came within feet of one of the officers before he was shot in what Dotson described as a "suicide by cop," according to ABC News.

 “If you’re the family of a police officer and somebody approaches you within three feet with a knife, I think you have the right to defend yourself and protect yourself,” Dotson said. “I think it certainly is reasonable that an officer has an expectation to go home at the end of the night.”

Tuesday’s shooting continued the chaos that has engulfed the area around Ferguson, Missouri, where unarmed 18-year-old Michael Brown was shot and killed Aug. 9 by Ferguson police officer Darren Wilson.

The FBI, Justice Department and local authorities are investigating Brown’s death. An autopsy conducted for the family by medical examiner Dr. Michael Baden was released Sunday, revealing that Brown had been shot six times in his altercation with Wilson – twice in the head.

Brown’s death sparked days of looting, protesting and violence as Ferguson security forces struggled to maintain order. A brief window of peaceful protests last week gave the community a reprieve from consecutive nights of violence following Brown’s death, according to {CNN}<hyperlink=” http://www.cnn.com/2014/08/15/us/missouri-teen-shooting/index.html”>.

That calm dissolved over the weekend as violence prompted police officers this week to bring tear gas and riot gear back into the fray.

Officers “came under heavy gunfire” Monday night but did reportedly did not fire back at the rioters.
“This was not an act of protesters. This was an act of violent criminals,” Missouri State Highway Patrol Capt. Ron Johnson said Tuesday. “Protesters are peaceful and respectful. They don’t clash with police. They don’t throw Molotov cocktails.”

At least 31 people were arrested Monday night into Tuesday morning, according to {The Los Angeles Times}<hyperlink=”http://www.latimes.com/nation/nationnow/la-na-nn-ferguson-overnight-unrest-20140818-story.html”>. Some of those taken into custody were reportedly from California and New York.

Ferguson residents have claimed that some protesters not native to Ferguson have created trouble for the actual residents of the St. Louis suburb.

“Who would burn down their own backyard?” Ferguson resident Rebecca McCloud asked Sunday, according to {Fox News}<hyperlink=”http://www.foxnews.com/us/2014/08/17/police-try-to-disperse-protesters-defying-ferguson-curfew.html”>. “These people aren’t from here. They came to burn down our city and leave.”

The Missouri National Guard was called into Ferguson Monday to help maintain order. Missouri Gov. Jay Nixon has said that the Guard will primarily oversee the protection of Ferguson police forces’ command center, according to {The New York Times}<hyperlink=”http://www.nytimes.com/2014/08/20/us/ferguson-missouri-protests.html?_r=0”>.

“With these additional resources in place … the Missouri State Highway Patrol and local law enforcement will continue to respond appropriately to incidents of lawlessness and violence and protect the civil rights of all peaceful citizens to make their voices heard,” Nixon said Monday.

Attorney General Eric Holder is scheduled to travel to Ferguson Wednesday.

“Ours is a nation of laws: of citizens who live under them and for the citizens who enforce them,” President Barack Obama said in a press conference Monday. “Let me call once again for us to seek some understanding rather than simply holler at each other. Let’s seek to heal rather than to wound each other.
TheShitBetween: A 23-year-old man brandishing a knife was reportedly shot and killed by police officers just miles from the chaos in Ferguson, Missouri.

Title: What's Old Is New Again in Ferguson
Author: Jamie Stiehm
ArticleText:
Ferguson, Missouri, has opened our eyes to old and new unpleasant truths about the U.S. of A. First, a small Southern town burning over race – that’s a story we know by heart. American history and literature foretell it over and over: the South is the South is the South.

What's new to our eyes is the extent to which police forces have become militarized against the citizenry. Why we should tolerate police officers on tanks, looking like warriors, wielding heavy artillery, is beyond me. It’s another outrageous gift from the presidency of George W. Bush, who founded the Department of “Homeland Security.” The word “homeland” was not even in American usage before 2001. Now with military surplus hardware going out to law enforcement, the face of policing at home has changed to become more hostile in a post-9/11 posture. Violence on civilians is thus more likely to happen. 

Because of Ferguson, black anger and grief at white power and force is now in starker relief than the nation has witnessed in years. As our collective conscience registers the death of an unarmed youth by a police officer, this is a good time – a crisis – to look back as well as forward. Michael Brown was slain, shot several times, caught in the crossfire on a summer night, like many other young black men before him. Emmett Till, a Chicago youth of 14, died a brutal death in the oppressive heat of Mississippi in 1955. All they did to deserve dying was nothing.

Missouri has always been contested ground, a border state with Southern slavery and culture, much like Maryland. It's the setting of the greatest American novel, all about the crucible of race. Mark Twain, a son of Missouri, wrote in "Huckleberry Finn" about runaway Huck and fugitive slave Jim seeking freedom, rafting on the Mississippi River, away from the slave state Missouri. How stark is that imagery in our shared memory? If you've ever seen Hannibal, the riverfront town that was Twain's boyhood home, you can breathe that languorous Southern air that keeps people in their place. Missouri is far from the self-reliant Midwest in origins and character, contrary to reputation. It’s more Southern, not so much heartland.

One thing I will say in Missouri's favor is that President Harry Truman, a native son, desegregated the armed forces soon after World War II. Good for Harry.

Missouri was a slave state in antebellum America and the focus of festering debate in Congress during the bitter divide between North and South. The "Missouri Compromise" of 1820 was just the first skirmish. In the 150 years since the Civil War, in the 50 years since the landmark civil rights acts, we are still prisoners of the past. Reconciliation is far from complete. Racial relations still smolder in the former slave states – known as "the Slave power," among the abolitionists who resisted it. Philadelphia Quakers and Bostonian Unitarians shone as anti-slavery leaders from the 1830s to the 1850s. These decades were our darkest historical hours.

We still have an unspoken fault line, descended from the Mason-Dixon Line that separated freedom and slavery. Not all states were created equal, let's be honest. The leading states standing against slavery were Ohio, Pennsylvania, Massachusetts and New York. That's just the truth. But old Missouri still has the weight of slavery hanging over it, our own American "peculiar institution." It remains somewhere under the sun, painfully re-enacted in variations to this day.

Just ask Michael Brown.
TheShitBetween: The tensions in Missouri are part of a too-familiar American story.

Title: Views You Can Use: Who Is Listening to Who in Ferguson?
Author: Teresa Welsh
ArticleText:
Protests in Ferguson, Missouri, again turned violent over the weekend in response to the shooting death of 18-year-old Michael Brown, who was killed by police officer Darren Wilson on August 9. Unsurprisingly, {a new Pew poll}<hyperlink=”http://www.people-press.org/2014/08/18/stark-racial-divisions-in-reactions-to-ferguson-police-shooting/”> finds that race itself impacts reactions as to whether or not Brown’s death “raises important issues about race or whether the issue of race is getting more attention than it deserves.” Pew found that “[b]y about four-to-one (80% to 18%), African Americans say the shooting in Ferguson raises important issues about race that merit discussion. By contrast, whites, by 47% to 37%, say the issue of race is getting more attention than it deserves.”

 “The most interesting data point in the new Pew poll though,” wrote {Aaron Blake for the Fix}<hyperlink=”https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-fix/wp/2014/08/18/racial-reactions-to-ferguson-even-stronger-than-to-trayvon-martin/”>, “is that even at this very early juncture, Americans as a whole see the shooting of Brown as more of a racial issue than the shooting of [Florida teen Trayvon] Martin by neighborhood watch volunteer George Zimmerman.”

Ferguson, a St. Louis suburb, doesn’t see high black political participation because the Democratic institutions that mobilize voters in the city haven’t been established yet in the suburbs, where blacks have flocked only in the last 15 years, wrote {Jeff Smith for the New York Times}<hyperlink=”http://www.nytimes.com/2014/08/18/opinion/in-ferguson-black-town-white-power.html”>. “That helps explain why majority-black Ferguson has a virtually all-white power structure: a white mayor; a school board with six white members and one Hispanic, which recently suspended a highly regarded young black superintendent who then resigned; a City Council with just one black member; and a 6 percent black police force," Smith wrote.

The racial disparities in public representation in Ferguson are also caused by “the fact that municipal elections in Ferguson are held not just in off-years, but in April instead of November. While turnout among whites and blacks in the 2012 presidential election was identical, whites turned out for Ferguson’s April 2013 municipal election at a rate nearly three times that of blacks,” wrote {Paul Waldman for the Washington Post}<hyperlink=”https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/plum-line/wp/2014/08/18/what-libertarians-and-conservatives-get-wrong-about-ferguson/”>. “That disparity then has consequences that incorporate law enforcement, economics, and people’s daily interactions with authority.”

Those authorities have had a difficult time containing violence in the wake of the shooting death, resulting in Gov. Jay Nixon ordering the Missouri National Guard to Ferguson. No one should be encouraging more protests, wrote {Gary Younge for the Guardian}<hyperlink=”http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2014/aug/18/ferguson-violence-martin-luther-king-michael-brown”>, and no one wants more unarmed black teens shot, either. “And those two things – the violence of the state and the violence of the street – are connected,” Younge wrote. “The people on the streets don’t donate thousands of dollars to anyone’s campaign. They don’t get a seat at any table where decisions are made or have the ear of the powerful. But with four black men killed by the police in the country in the last four weeks, they have a lot to say, and precious few avenues through which to say it. The question now is who’s listening.”
TheShitBetween: Americans have different reactions to the shooting based upon their own race.

Title: Missouri Highway Patrol Had Data to Back-up Fairness in Ferguson
Author: Lindsey Cook
ArticleText:
Racial tension in Ferguson is nothing new. As we wrote yesterday, {the police department had a history of racial profiling}<hyperlink=”http://www.usnews.com/news/blogs/data-mine/2014/08/14/racial-tensions-in-ferguson-started-long-before-dontshoot”> that remained mostly constant over the last decade.
Earlier this week the Ferguson Police Department alongside the St. Louis County Department {met residents with tear gas}<hyperlink=”http://www.usnews.com/news/articles/2014/08/14/press-not-targeted-in-tear-gas-attack-missouri-sheriffs-department-spokesman-says”>, tanks and military-like weapons, aggravating protesters and the country, who watched the mess unfold through pictures and {video of residents fleeing smoke bombs}<hyperlink=”http://launch.newsinc.com/embed.html?type=VideoPlayer/16x9&videoId=26519013&trackingGroup=90080&widgetId=27469&playlistId=994&siteSection=usnews_hom_non_fro&embedOriginUrl=http%253A%252F%252Fwww.usnews.com%252Fnews%252Fnewsgram%252Farticles%252F2014%252F08%252F15%252Fferguson-police-chief-names-darren-wilson-as-officer-involved-in-michael-brown-shooting”>. Some, likened the appearance of {police to that of U.S. military forces}<hyperlink=”http://www.usnews.com/news/articles/2014/08/14/michael-brown-eric-garner-deaths-add-scrutiny-to-broken-windows-policing”> in Iraq and {Palestinians took to twitter}<hyperlink=”http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/northamerica/usa/11036190/Palestinians-tweet-tear-gas-advice-to-protesters-in-Ferguson.html”> to advise Ferguson residents on dealing with tear gas.
On Thursday, {Missouri State Highway Patrol Capt. Ronald Johnson}<hyperlink=”http://www.usnews.com/news/newsgram/articles/2014/08/15/ferguson-police-chief-names-darren-wilson-as-officer-involved-in-michael-brown-shooting”> was put in charge of maintaining the peace. He has done a good job, too. As reported in a news conference Friday morning, there weren't any arrests Thursday night.
The change isn't surprising, after looking at the Highway Patrol's own data on racial profiling. The {Missouri State Attorney General's Office}<hyperlink=”http://ago.mo.gov/VehicleStops/Reports.php?lea=720”> maintains a "disparity index" for each police department, which compares the amount of police stops of a racial or ethnic group with the group's population in the community. 
Both Ferguson and St. Louis County both score poorly.
A score of 1 indicates no disparity, higher than 1 is an over-representation and less than 1 is an under-representation. Both departments have scored above 1 during the last decade. The statewide statistics are even worse. 
The Missouri Highway Patrol, however, doesn't have the same disparity.
TheShitBetween: New police responded to residents with hugs instead of tear gas.

Title: Unrest Abounds in Ferguson as Journalists, Official Arrested
Author: Andrew Soergel
ArticleText:
Eric Garner was accused of selling untaxed cigarettes in Staten Island when a police officer put him in the illegal choke hold that killed him. Michael Brown and a friend were walking in the middle of street in a St. Louis suburb, drawing the attention of a local cop who ended up shooting and killing the unarmed Brown. An “investigative stop” by police resulted in the death of Ezell Ford, a Los Angeles man, {who witnesses}<hyperlink=”http://ktla.com/2014/08/12/man-hospitalized-after-being-shot-by-police-in-south-l-a/”> say was shot three times while he was already compliantly lying on the ground.

Taken together, the instances of unarmed, black men getting shot and killed under debatable circumstances have put new scrutiny on a police tactic known as “broken windows,” in which law enforcement officers focus on rooting out minor disorder as a way to prevent more serious crime. Critics say the tactic unfairly targets minority and poor communities and fosters a culture of police brutality.

 “The death of Michael Brown strikes me as the latest, sad chapter in an ongoing national narrative about a form of policing, broken windows policing, that is simply not right for the country,” says Cornell William Brooks, national president of the NAACP. “We have a number of incidents where we have young people who are at worst suspected of underwhelming, minor offenses who meet an overwhelming, major – sometimes lethal – use of force that leads to tragedy.”

Rep. Hakeem Jeffries, D-N.Y., along with five fellow members of the New York congressional delegation, {have called on}<hyperlink=”http://www.nytimes.com/2014/08/14/nyregion/six-members-of-congress-ask-holder-to-open-federal-inquiry-in-chokehold-case.html”> Attorney General Eric Holder to intervene in the investigation of Garner’s death as well as examine more broadly the broken windows policing strategy.

“Racially selective law enforcement that focuses heavily on communities of color runs a serious risk of violating the constitution and federal civil rights laws,” Jeffries says. “Minor offenses are either subject to enforcement or they are not. But they cannot be offenses that are enforced in some communities while being ignored in other communities when the dividing line is race.”

Broken windows gets its name from {an Atlantic article}<hyperlink=”http://www.theatlantic.com/magazine/archive/1982/03/broken-windows/304465/?single_page=true”> written by the theory’s authors, criminologists George Kelling and James Wilson , introducing their approach in 1982. A building with one broken window is likely to be continually vandalized if left unrepaired, the theory goes, and thus by cracking down on minor infractions, communities can ward off more serious crimes.

"If the neighborhood cannot keep a bothersome panhandler from annoying passers-by, the thief may reason, it is even less likely to call the police to identify a potential mugger or to interfere if the mugging actually takes place,” Kelling and Wilson wrote.

The article and further scholarship that accompanied it were hugely influential in shaping policing protocols in the 1980s and 1990s. The vast majority of police departments incorporate the model in their approaches, according to John Firman, director of research at the International Association of Chiefs of Police, which represents 18,000 state and local law enforcement agencies nationwide.

“Police around the country have embraced the concept almost universally, because it is so elegant,” he says.

However, questions continue about whether in practice the theory works as neatly as it sounds.

The way it was originally described by Kelling and Wilson, broken windows strategy could include a variety of solutions and interpretations, not all of them having to do with traditional policing. For instance to address a rampant graffiti problem, officials could instruct cops to more harshly punish those caught doing graffiti, or hire more sanitation crews to diligently clean up the vandalism.

In effect, "broken windows" has become a kind of catchall phrase for all sorts of policing approaches it inspired, including what is known as “community-oriented policing” or “problem-solving policing.” Some cities, namely New York, continue to embrace the broken windows approach explicitly, as New York Police Commissioner William Bratton considers Kelling {his intellectual mentor}<hyperlink=”http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=249074812”>. In other cities, it has manifested itself in efforts like a 1990s Chicago ordinance that allowed police to arrest people for loitering under the suspicion that they were gang members; a measure {ultimately struck down by the Supreme Court}<hyperlink=”http://www.nytimes.com/1999/06/11/us/loitering-law-aimed-at-gangs-is-struck-down-by-high-court.html”>.

In its decades of use, broken windows policing proponents have pointed to research, including {that of Wesley Skogan}<hyperlink=”https://books.google.com/books/about/Disorder_and_Decline.html?id=ASrAMJh7LngC&hl=en”>, which has shown an empirical connection between disorder in a community (i.e. the minor infractions targeted by broken window policing) and overall crime rates.

However, other studies, particularly the {work done by Bernard Harcourt}<hyperlink=”https://books.google.com/books?id=mSWDy1kGUGAC&pg=PA59&lpg=PA59&dq=broken+windows+policing+wesley+skogan&source=bl&ots=zmK92_86ot&sig=tEFuKzNV6SzaXByYgeIhrUa7gjQ&hl=en&sa=X&ei=ctbsU5i4H6nlsASysoDIDQ&sqi=2&ved=0CGsQ6AEwCA#v=onepage&q=broken%20windows%20policing%20wesley%20skogan&f=false”>, shed doubt on Skogan’s analysis as well as the effectiveness of broken windows policing as a whole.

“It turns out that a lot of ways broken windows policing defines orderliness is not always in tune with the community’s norms,” Harcourt says. “Broken windows policing would define disorderliness as a group of neighbors sitting on a stoop. Well it turns out that in some neighborhoods, that’s a form of control of a neighborhood ordering itself by knowing who is coming in and out of the neighborhood.”

It is a theory that often relies too much on discretion, critics say, and that discretion, in turn, can lead to racial and class bias.

“What has proven to be true in these interactions – sometimes resulting in police violence, otherwise resulting in simple abuse of authority and hurt feelings – is that these officers tend not to respect poor black and brown people,” says Khalil Gibran Muhammad, author of “The Condemnation of Blackness: Race, Crime and the Making of Modern Urban America.”


Such tactics, critics say, foster an environment where black and Hispanic communities harbor deep mistrust of the institutions ostensibly in charge of protecting them, particularly when the authorities they're dealing with are mostly white. Long-term, underlying policing issues in Ferguson prompted Jerryl Christmas, a defense attorney and former St. Louis prosecutor, {to call the town}<hyperlink=”http://www.latimes.com/nation/nationnow/la-na-missouri-st-louis-police-shooting-teen-20140811-story.html#page=”> “a racial powder keg.” The explosiveness of police-community relations in Ferguson were on full display with Wednesday evening’s crackdown on local protesters involving {a police response akin to a military action}<hyperlink=”http://www.usnews.com/news/articles/2014/08/14/ferguson-and-the-shocking-nature-of-us-police-militarization”>.

"The cop harassment is frequent. It's all through the day, it's all through the night. When they're not beating us physically, they're doing it verbally," Robert X, a Ferguson resident participating in this week's protests, {described to The New York Times}<hyperlink=”http://www.nytimes.com/video/us/100000003055806/standoff-with-police-in-ferguson.html?smid=tw-nytvideo&seid=auto”>. "This has been going on before Michael Brown, It's been going on before {Trayvon Martin}<hyperlink=”http://www.usnews.com/news/articles/2014/07/18/a-year-after-trayvon-martin-who-is-leading-the-race-conversation”>, before {Emmett Till}<hyperlink=”http://www.pbs.org/wgbh/amex/till/”>. It's been going on a long time."

Kelling, now a senior fellow at the conservative think-tank the Manhattan Institute, continues to defend broken windows policing. He tells U.S. News he didn't see how broken windows was related to the controversies over Garner’s and Brown’s death.

“When people don’t obey the law, the police are going to intervene,” he says. “What happened in New York​​​​​... ​had tragic outcomes and sadly that happened and we don’t know the details. But the idea of that just because police are enforcing the law, that we expect that because there is a risk of something bad happening, that police should not enforce the law? There’s a demand out there that people do things about particular problems.” 
To the racial disparities in how it is enforced, he says, “Who are the victims of crime and where are people victimized? It turns out they’re in minority and poor neighborhoods. To put police where crimes are and where victims are, they’re going to be running into those minority and those poor citizens. That is just a basic reality.”

Kelling does, however, concede:​ “There are times that in the name of broken windows, bad policing has taken place.”

“It’s a highly discretionary activity and for the most part I’ve encouraged police to educate, to warn and only use arrest as a last resort. Arrest is a powerful tool as well and should only be used sparingly,” he says.

{A New York Daily News report}<hyperlink=”http://www.nydailynews.com/new-york/summons-broken-windows-racial-disparity-garner-article-1.1890567”> on the enforcement of broken windows in New York found the policy resulted annually in hundreds of thousand of low-level violations, court summons and arrests over the last decade or so. In a vast majority of violations – 81 percent – those punished were black and Hispanic, and summons were mostly issued in black and Hispanic majority communities.

Likewise in Ferguson, there {have been reports}<hyperlink=”https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/even-before-teen-michael-browns-slaying-in-mo-racial-questions-have-hung-over-police/2014/08/13/78b3c5c6-2307-11e4-86ca-6f03cbd15c1a_story.html?hpid=z2”> of long-standing tensions between the largely white police force and the 67 percent black community. For instance, 86 percent of drivers pulled over by police were black and, when those stops ended in arrest, 92 percent of those arrested were black, according to {The Washington Post}<hyperlink=”https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/post-nation/wp/2014/08/12/the-breaking-point-for-ferguson/”>.

"We have people who have warrants because of traffic tickets and are effectively imprisoned in their homes,” Malik Ahmed, the CEO of Better Family Life, a St. Louis community development organization, {told The New Yorker}<hyperlink=”http://www.newyorker.com/news/news-desk/saw-ferguson”>. "They can’t go outside because they’ll be arrested. In some cases people actually have jobs but decide the threat of arrest makes it not worth trying to commute outside their neighborhood.”

Garner's Staten Island and Brown's Ferguson are very different places, but both share a lower-income, minority community that faces heavy punishments for minor offenses.

“Conceptually, to the extent broken windows is an enforcement strategy that is applied equally in every community throughout America, there is no constitutional problem,” Rep. Jeffries says. “But what we see in practice is that the broken windows strategy is largely deployed in black and Latino communities,that is why we’ve requested the Department of Justice to look into the manner in which the strategy has been applied.”

The Department of Justice​ is conducting a broad review of police tactics across the country, {USA Today reported}<hyperlink=”http://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2014/08/12/police-force-panel/13951033/?utm_source=dlvr.it&utm_medium=twitter&dlvrit=206567”> Wednesday. The agency did not respond to U.S. News requests for comment as to whether this review would include broken windows policing​. However Holder has signaled that, at least in Ferguson, the priority is on cooling the long-boiling frustrations that predated Brown's death.

“Department officials from the Community Relations Service are also on the ground in Missouri to help convene law enforcement officials and civic and faith leaders to plot out steps to reduce tensions in the community," Holder said in a {press release}<hyperlink=”http://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/statement-attorney-general-eric-holder-latest-developments-ferguson-missouri”> Thursday. "The latest such meeting was convened in Ferguson as recently as this morning. Over time, these conversations should consider the role that increased diversity in law enforcement can play in helping to build trust within communities. All the while, the federal civil rights investigation into the shooting incident itself continues, in parallel with the local investigation into state law violations."
TheShitBetween: Reports of sweeping arrests in Missouri surface as crowds clash with riot gear-clad police force.

Title: Ferguson Police Name Officer Who Shot and Killed Unarmed Black Teen
Author: David A. Lieb; Alan Scher Zagier
ArticleText:
Ferguson Police Chief Thomas Jackson made the announcement after initially declining to the release the name, saying the officer had received numerous death threats. The officer has been on administrative leave since the shooting Saturday of 18-year-old Michael Brown, whose death has sparked several days of clashes with furious protesters.

But on Thursday, county police in riot gear and armored tanks gave way to state troopers walking side-by-side with thousands of peaceful protesters. The dramatic shift came after Gov. Jay Nixon assigned oversight of the protests to the state Highway Patrol, stripping that authority from the St. Louis County Police Department.

"All they did was look at us and shoot tear gas," Pedro Smith, who has participated in the nightly protests, said Thursday. "This is totally different. Now we're being treated with respect."

The more tolerant response came as President Barack Obama spoke publicly for the first time about Saturday's fatal shooting — and the subsequent violence that shocked the nation and threatened to tear apart Ferguson, a town of 21,000 that is nearly 70 percent black and patrolled by a nearly all-white police force.

Obama said there was "no excuse" for violence either against the police or by officers against peaceful protesters.

Tensions boiled over after a candlelight vigil Sunday night, as looters smashed and burned businesses in the neighborhood, where police have repeatedly fired tear gas and smoke bombs.

Police have said Brown was shot after an officer encountered him and another man on the street. They say one of the men pushed the officer into his squad car, then physically assaulted him in the vehicle and struggled with the officer over the officer's weapon. At least one shot was fired inside the car before the struggle spilled onto the street, where Brown was shot multiple times, according to police.

But a much different story has been told by Dorian Johnson, who says he was walking down the street with Brown when he was shot. He has said the officer ordered them out of the street, then grabbed his friend's neck and tried to pull him into the car before brandishing his weapon and firing. He says Brown started to run and the officer pursued him, firing multiple times.

Nixon's promise to ease the deep racial tensions was swiftly put to the test as demonstrators gathered again Thursday evening. But the latest protests had a light, almost jubilant atmosphere among the racially mixed crowd, more akin to a parade or block party.

The streets were filled with music, free food and even laughter. When darkness fell — the point at which previous protests have grown tense — no uniformed officers were in sight outside the burned-out QuikTrip convenience store that had become a flashpoint for standoffs between police and protesters.

"You can feel it. You can see it," protester Cleo Willis said of the change. "Now it's up to us to ride that feeling."

Nixon appointed Highway Patrol Capt. Ron Johnson, who is black, to lead the police effort. Johnson, who grew up near Ferguson and commands a region that includes St. Louis County, marched alongside protesters Thursday, joined by other high-ranking brass from the Highway Patrol as well as the county department. The marchers also had a police escort.

"We're here to serve and protect," Johnson said. "We're not here to instill fear."

Residents in Ferguson have complained about the police response that began soon after Brown's shooting with the use of dogs for crowd control — a tactic that for some evoked civil-rights protests from a half-century ago. The county police had taken over the investigation of Brown's shooting and security at the request of Ferguson.

Nixon vowed that "Ferguson will not be defined as a community that was torn apart by violence but will be known as a community that pulled together to overcome it." The governor was joined at a news conference by the white mayor of St. Louis and the region's four state representatives and the county executive, all of whom are black.

Attorney General Eric Holder has said federal investigators have interviewed witnesses to the shooting.
TheShitBetween: NA

Title: Libertarians Face a Ferguson Challenge
Author: Nicole Hemmer
ArticleText:
Last week, Kentucky Sen. Rand Paul wrote (a pointed response}<hyperlink” http://time.com/3111474/rand-paul-ferguson-police/”> to the crisis developing in Ferguson, Missouri: “If I had been told to get out of the street as a teenager, there would have been a distinct possibility that I might have smarted off. But, I wouldn’t have expected to be shot.” He went on to criticize the militarization of the police and the racial injustices of the American legal system. As Paul put it, “Anyone who thinks that race does not still, even if inadvertently, skew the application of criminal justice in this country is just not paying close enough attention.”

Coming from a libertarian Republican who is considered a frontrunner for the 2016 nomination, Paul’s comments were much anticipated. For a few days after Michael Brown was killed, libertarian leader {remained fairly quiet}<hyperlink=”https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/plum-line/wp/2014/08/13/why-arent-libertarians-talking-about-ferguson/”>, uncertain whether Brown’s death would be a matter of civil rights or civil liberties. It may sound like a small difference, but it’s an important one. When it comes to issues framed in terms of civil rights, libertarians tend to opt out. They led the charge against national ID cards but not voter ID laws, against Transportation Security Administration body scans but not TSA racial profiling.

In Ferguson, libertarian leaders have a chance to change this, to defend not only civil liberties but civil rights. To do so, however, will require rethinking some of their core assumptions about government power.

The crisis in Ferguson meets at the intersection of civil liberties and civil rights. The two terms, though quite similar, point in opposite directions. “Civil liberties” suggests the encroachment of a too-powerful state. “Civil rights,” on the other hand, typically applies to issues of discrimination and inequality that require the federal government to intervene. Libertarians thus harbor suspicions toward the federal government, while civil rights activists look to it for support.

These opposing impulses have historically pitted libertarians against civil rights activists. Barry Goldwater in 1964 declared his opposition to the Civil Rights Act in libertarian terms. While believing racial discrimination was abhorrent, Goldwater insisted the federal government had neither the authority nor the ability to legislate it away.

It is a position many libertarians have clung to in the decades since. Rep. Ron Paul declared his opposition to the Civil Rights Act in 2004, a position his son Rand Paul seemed to defend in {a 2010 interview}<hyperlink=”http://thinkprogress.org/politics/2010/05/19/98217/paul-civil-rights/”>  in which he said, among other things, “I think it’s a bad business decision to exclude anybody from your restaurant — but, at the same time, I do believe in private ownership.”


That apparent defense of his father’s position did not go over well, and in May 2013 {Paul came out firmly in favor}<hyperlink”https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/fact-checker/post/rand-pauls-rewriting-of-his-own-remarks-on-the-civil-rights-act/2013/04/10/5b8d91c4-a235-11e2-82bc-511538ae90a4_blog.html”> of the 1964 Civil Rights Act, telling Wolf Blitzer, “There was an overriding problem in the south so big that it did require federal intervention” and thus he would have voted for the bill. In making those comments, Paul abandoned what had been libertarian orthodoxy: choosing a philosophical opposition to federal power over the actual protection of individual freedoms.

This tendency to support libertarian means over libertarian ends has been a major problem for the movement, which is why political observers were so keen to hear how libertarians would respond to the crisis in Ferguson. The militarization of the police, so clearly on display in Ferguson, has been an important topic for libertarian thinkers like {Radley Balko}<hyperlink=”https://www.washingtonpost.com/people/radley-balko”>. But what was happening in Ferguson was also an issue of civil rights, raising questions of racial profiling, residential segregation and economic inequality.

Paul offered a resolution that squared the circle: blaming the federal government for the crisis. “Washington,” he wrote, shifting his gaze from local law enforcement to distant D.C., “has incentivized the militarization of local police precincts by using federal dollars to help municipal governments build what are essentially small armies.”

He’s right: First through the War on Drugs and then the War on Terror, federal initiatives have vested local law enforcement and criminal justice authorities with unprecedented power. As we’ve learned in the past week, cops in Keene, New Hampshire, safeguard the town’s 23,000 citizens with armored personnel carriers and officers in Doraville, Georgia (pop: 8,500) are kitted out with tanks and camouflage.

Prosecutors, meanwhile, have the power to pile on charges so that criminal trials are no longer worth the risk. As of 2009, 97 percent of federal cases and 94 percent of state cases {ended in plea bargains}<hyperlink=”http://www.nytimes.com/2012/03/23/us/stronger-hand-for-judges-after-rulings-on-plea-deals.html”>. The overwhelming power of the state tilts the scales of justice throughout the legal system, and minorities are often the ones most affected.

Still, it’s hard to imagine a long-term partnership between libertarians and civil rights activists. For the last 150 years, the protection of minority civil rights has required a strong federal state: to end slavery, to protect freed people, to dismantle Jim Crow, to safeguard the ballot box. For nearly a century, local law enforcement terrorized black southerners. The federal government was the only level of government that would help (and even it had to be dragged kicking and screaming into the fight). Given a choice between Bull Connor and Bobby Kennedy, is it any wonder black southerners preferred far-off feds to close-at-hand cops?

That history informs the crisis unfolding in Ferguson, where there is little evidence that black residents agree with Paul’s argument that “big government has been at the heart of the problem.” They are, understandably, far more likely to trust Attorney General Eric Holder, who arrives in Ferguson on Wednesday, than officers in the Ferguson Police Department, some of whom in 2009 {assaulted a black man}<hyperlink=”http://www.nytimes.com/2012/03/23/us/stronger-hand-for-judges-after-rulings-on-plea-deals.html”> in their custody, then charged him with destruction of property for getting blood on their uniforms.

Ferguson, then, presents a challenge as well as an opportunity for libertarians. Yes, they can make tactical alliances with civil rights leaders. But that alliance will be short-lived if libertarians remain rigid in their insistence that a strong government endangers rather than engenders liberty. If libertarians like Paul can embrace a more nuanced understanding of government power, they can advance not only civil liberties, but civil rights as well.
TheShitBetween: The crisis in Missouri provides libertarians with a chance to support civil liberties and civil rights.

Title: Don't Rush to Prosecute Ferguson Cop, George Zimmerman Lawyer Says
Author: Steven Nelson
ArticleText:
After nearly a week of protests, police in Ferguson, Missouri, on Friday identified the officer who shot and killed 18-year-old Michael Brown.

Darren Wilson, the triggerman, is a four-year employee of the Ferguson Police Department and was responding to a nearby robbery, Ferguson Police Chief Thomas Jackson said. The chief said Wilson was treated for physical injuries after the Saturday incident.

The case has many similarities to the Trayvon Martin shooting and subsequent media whirlwind. Martin, 17, was shot dead in February 2012 by neighborhood watch volunteer George Zimmerman, who was charged with murder after an intense public pressure campaign featuring protests in Sanford, Florida, and wall-to-wall media coverage. A jury found Zimmerman not guilty in July 2013.

Zimmerman successfully argued that he defended himself when Martin, who was unarmed, attacked. The public face of his defense team, attorney Mark O’Mara, tells U.S. News prosecutors in Missouri should resist calls to promptly file charges against Wilson.

Many facts about the Brown case are unknown. For example, authorities haven’t said how many shots were fired by the policeman. It’s also unclear what injuries the officer allegedly suffered.

“I said in Zimmerman and I have to echo it here today, we know so little about what led up to this, what happened between them,” O’Mara says. 

Any decision about charges should be presented to a grand jury, he says, rather than made unilaterally by a prosecutor, as was done in the Martin case.

O’Mara says it will be important to look at evidence and witness statements in their entirety. In the Zimmerman case, for example, it wasn’t immediately known to the public that the shooter suffered a gash to the back of his head, which became a key piece of the case.

“A swollen cheek, will that be relevant? Sure,” O’Mara says. “Every fact is going to be relevant: Every eyewitness, the movement of the car, the injuries, the injuries to Michael Brown – but what we don’t want to do is take one snippet and say, ‘Aha, here’s the answer,' because that’s exactly what happened in Zimmerman. The emergency call came out and it was interpreted, misinterpreted by most, and then they let out this and then they let out a medical record and then they let out a 12-year-old photo of Trayvon – and all of this information fell into this vacuum of information and most of it was at least incomplete if not inaccurate.”

He says authorities should also withhold key details about the case before completing their investigation.

“If you let out one piece of information, some other witness customizes or re-remembers their testimony to take into consideration that piece of evidence and now you’ve infected the testimony,” he says.

O’Mara isn’t exactly leaping to the defense of local cops, who battled protesters in Ferguson with tear gas and rubber bullets throughout the week. He doesn’t like the {militarized}<hyperlink=”http://www.usnews.com/news/articles/2014/08/14/ferguson-and-the-shocking-nature-of-us-police-militarization”> reaction, though he also dislikes locals’ looting spree.

O’Mara says the ultimate fate of Wilson will come down to a careful second-by-second analysis of his actions.

“You have to look at it almost moment to moment,” he says. “If at the time the officer shot his weapon, he was protecting himself from what he perceived to be grave bodily injury, that’s self-defense. If the second shot was also under the same conditions, that’s self-defense. If it wasn’t, that’s not.”

Protesters in Ferguson and around the country allege that Brown was shot with his hands in the air.

Dorian Johnson, 22, {told MSNBC}<hyperlink=”http://www.msnbc.com/msnbc/eyewitness-michael-brown-fatal-shooting-missouri”> earlier this week the officer now identified as Wilson grabbed Brown around the neck and then shot him as Brown pulled away. Johnson said Brown then ran away and was shot a second time, in the back. Brown then said, "I don’t have a gun, stop shooting!" according to his friend, but was shot several more times.

Police reports {name}<hyperlink=”http://i2.cdn.turner.com/cnn/2014/images/08/15/ferguson.police.documents.pdf”> Johnson and Brown as suspects in the theft of cigars from a store earlier that day. Police released images of the robbery on Friday. No video or photos of the shooting have surfaced, but accounts thus far agree Brown was unarmed.

In a sign of the parallels to the Martin case, Benjamin Crump, the Martin family’s attorney, is now representing the Brown family. "That baby was executed in broad daylight,” Crump said at a Monday press conference, according to MSNBC.
TheShitBetween: 'Every fact is going to be relevant,' says Mark O'Mara.

Title: From Ferguson to Staten Island, Questions About Broken Window Policing
Author: Tierney Sneed
ArticleText:
Eric Garner was accused of selling untaxed cigarettes in Staten Island when a police officer put him in the illegal choke hold that killed him. Michael Brown and a friend were walking in the middle of street in a St. Louis suburb, drawing the attention of a local cop who ended up shooting and killing the unarmed Brown. An “investigative stop” by police resulted in the death of Ezell Ford, a Los Angeles man, {who witnesses}<hyperlink=”http://ktla.com/2014/08/12/man-hospitalized-after-being-shot-by-police-in-south-l-a/”> say was shot three times while he was already compliantly lying on the ground.

Taken together, the instances of unarmed, black men getting shot and killed under debatable circumstances have put new scrutiny on a police tactic known as “broken windows,” in which law enforcement officers focus on rooting out minor disorder as a way to prevent more serious crime. Critics say the tactic unfairly targets minority and poor communities and fosters a culture of police brutality.

 “The death of Michael Brown strikes me as the latest, sad chapter in an ongoing national narrative about a form of policing, broken windows policing, that is simply not right for the country,” says Cornell William Brooks, national president of the NAACP. “We have a number of incidents where we have young people who are at worst suspected of underwhelming, minor offenses who meet an overwhelming, major – sometimes lethal – use of force that leads to tragedy.”

Rep. Hakeem Jeffries, D-N.Y., along with five fellow members of the New York congressional delegation, {have called on}<hyperlink=”http://www.nytimes.com/2014/08/14/nyregion/six-members-of-congress-ask-holder-to-open-federal-inquiry-in-chokehold-case.html”> Attorney General Eric Holder to intervene in the investigation of Garner’s death as well as examine more broadly the broken windows policing strategy.

“Racially selective law enforcement that focuses heavily on communities of color runs a serious risk of violating the constitution and federal civil rights laws,” Jeffries says. “Minor offenses are either subject to enforcement or they are not. But they cannot be offenses that are enforced in some communities while being ignored in other communities when the dividing line is race.”

Broken windows gets its name from {an Atlantic article}<hyperlink=”http://www.theatlantic.com/magazine/archive/1982/03/broken-windows/304465/?single_page=true”> written by the theory’s authors, criminologists George Kelling and James Wilson , introducing their approach in 1982. A building with one broken window is likely to be continually vandalized if left unrepaired, the theory goes, and thus by cracking down on minor infractions, communities can ward off more serious crimes.

"If the neighborhood cannot keep a bothersome panhandler from annoying passers-by, the thief may reason, it is even less likely to call the police to identify a potential mugger or to interfere if the mugging actually takes place,” Kelling and Wilson wrote.

The article and further scholarship that accompanied it were hugely influential in shaping policing protocols in the 1980s and 1990s. The vast majority of police departments incorporate the model in their approaches, according to John Firman, director of research at the International Association of Chiefs of Police, which represents 18,000 state and local law enforcement agencies nationwide.

“Police around the country have embraced the concept almost universally, because it is so elegant,” he says.

However, questions continue about whether in practice the theory works as neatly as it sounds.

The way it was originally described by Kelling and Wilson, broken windows strategy could include a variety of solutions and interpretations, not all of them having to do with traditional policing. For instance to address a rampant graffiti problem, officials could instruct cops to more harshly punish those caught doing graffiti, or hire more sanitation crews to diligently clean up the vandalism.

In effect, "broken windows" has become a kind of catchall phrase for all sorts of policing approaches it inspired, including what is known as “community-oriented policing” or “problem-solving policing.” Some cities, namely New York, continue to embrace the broken windows approach explicitly, as New York Police Commissioner William Bratton considers Kelling {his intellectual mentor}<hyperlink=”http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=249074812”>. In other cities, it has manifested itself in efforts like a 1990s Chicago ordinance that allowed police to arrest people for loitering under the suspicion that they were gang members; a measure {ultimately struck down by the Supreme Court}<hyperlink=”http://www.nytimes.com/1999/06/11/us/loitering-law-aimed-at-gangs-is-struck-down-by-high-court.html”>.

In its decades of use, broken windows policing proponents have pointed to research, including {that of Wesley Skogan}<hyperlink=”https://books.google.com/books/about/Disorder_and_Decline.html?id=ASrAMJh7LngC&hl=en”>, which has shown an empirical connection between disorder in a community (i.e. the minor infractions targeted by broken window policing) and overall crime rates.

However, other studies, particularly the {work done by Bernard Harcourt}<hyperlink=”https://books.google.com/books?id=mSWDy1kGUGAC&pg=PA59&lpg=PA59&dq=broken+windows+policing+wesley+skogan&source=bl&ots=zmK92_86ot&sig=tEFuKzNV6SzaXByYgeIhrUa7gjQ&hl=en&sa=X&ei=ctbsU5i4H6nlsASysoDIDQ&sqi=2&ved=0CGsQ6AEwCA#v=onepage&q=broken%20windows%20policing%20wesley%20skogan&f=false”>, shed doubt on Skogan’s analysis as well as the effectiveness of broken windows policing as a whole.

“It turns out that a lot of ways broken windows policing defines orderliness is not always in tune with the community’s norms,” Harcourt says. “Broken windows policing would define disorderliness as a group of neighbors sitting on a stoop. Well it turns out that in some neighborhoods, that’s a form of control of a neighborhood ordering itself by knowing who is coming in and out of the neighborhood.”

It is a theory that often relies too much on discretion, critics say, and that discretion, in turn, can lead to racial and class bias.

“What has proven to be true in these interactions – sometimes resulting in police violence, otherwise resulting in simple abuse of authority and hurt feelings – is that these officers tend not to respect poor black and brown people,” says Khalil Gibran Muhammad, author of “The Condemnation of Blackness: Race, Crime and the Making of Modern Urban America.”

Such tactics, critics say, foster an environment where black and Hispanic communities harbor deep mistrust of the institutions ostensibly in charge of protecting them, particularly when the authorities they're dealing with are mostly white. Long-term, underlying policing issues in Ferguson prompted Jerryl Christmas, a defense attorney and former St. Louis prosecutor, {to call the town}<hyperlink=”http://www.latimes.com/nation/nationnow/la-na-missouri-st-louis-police-shooting-teen-20140811-story.html#page=”> “a racial powder keg.” The explosiveness of police-community relations in Ferguson were on full display with Wednesday evening’s crackdown on local protesters involving {a police response akin to a military action}<hyperlink=”http://www.usnews.com/news/articles/2014/08/14/ferguson-and-the-shocking-nature-of-us-police-militarization”>.

"The cop harassment is frequent. It's all through the day, it's all through the night. When they're not beating us physically, they're doing it verbally," Robert X, a Ferguson resident participating in this week's protests, {described to The New York Times}<hyperlink=”http://www.nytimes.com/video/us/100000003055806/standoff-with-police-in-ferguson.html?smid=tw-nytvideo&seid=auto”>. "This has been going on before Michael Brown, It's been going on before {Trayvon Martin}<hyperlink=”http://www.usnews.com/news/articles/2014/07/18/a-year-after-trayvon-martin-who-is-leading-the-race-conversation”>, before {Emmett Till}<hyperlink=”http://www.pbs.org/wgbh/amex/till/”>. It's been going on a long time."


Kelling, now a senior fellow at the conservative think-tank the Manhattan Institute, continues to defend broken windows policing. He tells U.S. News he didn't see how broken windows was related to the controversies over Garner’s and Brown’s death.

“When people don’t obey the law, the police are going to intervene,” he says. “What happened in New York​​​​​... ​had tragic outcomes and sadly that happened and we don’t know the details. But the idea of that just because police are enforcing the law, that we expect that because there is a risk of something bad happening, that police should not enforce the law? There’s a demand out there that people do things about particular problems.” 
To the racial disparities in how it is enforced, he says, “Who are the victims of crime and where are people victimized? It turns out they’re in minority and poor neighborhoods. To put police where crimes are and where victims are, they’re going to be running into those minority and those poor citizens. That is just a basic reality.”

Kelling does, however, concede:​ “There are times that in the name of broken windows, bad policing has taken place.”

“It’s a highly discretionary activity and for the most part I’ve encouraged police to educate, to warn and only use arrest as a last resort. Arrest is a powerful tool as well and should only be used sparingly,” he says.

{A New York Daily News report}<hyperlink=”http://www.nydailynews.com/new-york/summons-broken-windows-racial-disparity-garner-article-1.1890567”> on the enforcement of broken windows in New York found the policy resulted annually in hundreds of thousand of low-level violations, court summons and arrests over the last decade or so. In a vast majority of violations – 81 percent – those punished were black and Hispanic, and summons were mostly issued in black and Hispanic majority communities.

Likewise in Ferguson, there {have been reports}<hyperlink=”https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/even-before-teen-michael-browns-slaying-in-mo-racial-questions-have-hung-over-police/2014/08/13/78b3c5c6-2307-11e4-86ca-6f03cbd15c1a_story.html?hpid=z2”> of long-standing tensions between the largely white police force and the 67 percent black community. For instance, 86 percent of drivers pulled over by police were black and, when those stops ended in arrest, 92 percent of those arrested were black, according to {The Washington Post}<hyperlink=”https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/post-nation/wp/2014/08/12/the-breaking-point-for-ferguson/”>.

"We have people who have warrants because of traffic tickets and are effectively imprisoned in their homes,” Malik Ahmed, the CEO of Better Family Life, a St. Louis community development organization, {told The New Yorker}<hyperlink=”http://www.newyorker.com/news/news-desk/saw-ferguson”>. "They can’t go outside because they’ll be arrested. In some cases people actually have jobs but decide the threat of arrest makes it not worth trying to commute outside their neighborhood.”

Garner's Staten Island and Brown's Ferguson are very different places, but both share a lower-income, minority community that faces heavy punishments for minor offenses.

“Conceptually, to the extent broken windows is an enforcement strategy that is applied equally in every community throughout America, there is no constitutional problem,” Rep. Jeffries says. “But what we see in practice is that the broken windows strategy is largely deployed in black and Latino communities,that is why we’ve requested the Department of Justice to look into the manner in which the strategy has been applied.”

The Department of Justice​ is conducting a broad review of police tactics across the country, {USA Today reported}<hyperlink=”http://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2014/08/12/police-force-panel/13951033/?utm_source=dlvr.it&utm_medium=twitter&dlvrit=206567”> Wednesday. The agency did not respond to U.S. News requests for comment as to whether this review would include broken windows policing​. However Holder has signaled that, at least in Ferguson, the priority is on cooling the long-boiling frustrations that predated Brown's death.

“Department officials from the Community Relations Service are also on the ground in Missouri to help convene law enforcement officials and civic and faith leaders to plot out steps to reduce tensions in the community," Holder said in a {press release}<hyperlink=”http://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/statement-attorney-general-eric-holder-latest-developments-ferguson-missouri”> Thursday. "The latest such meeting was convened in Ferguson as recently as this morning. Over time, these conversations should consider the role that increased diversity in law enforcement can play in helping to build trust within communities. All the while, the federal civil rights investigation into the shooting incident itself continues, in parallel with the local investigation into state law violations."
TheShitBetween: Critics say heavy-handed, racially biased tactics to blame for the deaths of Michael Brown and Eric Garner.
