Title: Was Missouri's Governor Right to Call in the National Guard?
Author: Rachel Brody
ArticleText:
Following continued unrest Sunday night, Missouri Democratic Gov. Jay Nixon ordered the National Guard to Ferguson, where police and civilians have clashed following the August 9 killing of Michael Brown, an unarmed black 18 year old.

Citing “conditions of distress and hazard” to city residents and property, Nixon deployed troops early Monday morning. “Tonight, a day of hope, prayers, and peaceful protests was marred by the violent criminal acts of an organized and growing number of individuals, many from outside the community and state, whose actions are putting the residents and businesses of Ferguson at risk,” Nixon said in {a statement}<hypertext=”https://governor.mo.gov/news/archive/following-coordinated-attacks-civilians-and-law-enforcement-governor-nixon-signs”>. Missouri National Guard Brigadier General Gregory Mason will be in charge of maintaining the peace, and the state-imposed curfew from midnight to 5 a.m. will not be in effect Monday night, Nixon said in his {most recent statement}<hypertext=”https://governor.mo.gov/news/archive/statement-gov-nixon-regarding-ongoing-situation-ferguson-and-role-national-guard”>.

Five days after the shooting, Nixon appointed Missouri Highway Patrol Capt. Ronald Johnson to take over policing from the Ferguson and St. Louis County Police departments. But Johnson, after {expressing sympathy and apologizing to Brown’s family just a day prior}<hypertext=”http://www.vox.com/2014/8/17/6028883/watch-capt-ron-johnsons-riveting-speech-at-ferguson-rally”>, said things had gotten out of hand by Monday morning. “There were shootings, vandalism and other acts of violence that clearly appear not to have been spontaneous but premeditated criminal acts,” Johnson {told reporters}<hypertext=”http://www.latimes.com/nation/nationnow/la-na-nn-ferguson-protest-curfew-20140817-story.html#page=1”> at a press conference. As violent protesters, armed with Molotov cocktails and bottles, moved toward the police command center Sunday night, officers launched tear gas canisters at the crowd. “Based on these conditions, I had no alternative but to elevate the level of our response,” Johnson said.

Key Smith, who traveled from Georgia to take part in a church rally for Brown, told {the New York Times}<hypertext=”http://www.nytimes.com/2014/08/19/us/ferguson-missouri-protests.html?_r=0”>, “This is getting out of hand,” referring to the violence in Ferguson. “It’s kind of sad that it’s come to this. If you really want to hit them in the right way, get out there and vote.” But other protesters expressed skepticism over the National Guard’s ability to quell violence. "If they [the National Guard] come, the more stuff that's going to happen," 22-year-old Michael Smith told {the Wall Street Journal}<hypertext=”http://www.wsj.com/articles/missouri-governor-deploys-national-guard-after-clashes-in-ferguson-1408348954”>.

Preliminary results of a private autopsy, released to the public on Monday, reveal that Brown was shot at least six times. U.S. Attorney General Eric Holder has called for a federal medical examiner to conduct a second autopsy, and the FBI has also opened a civil rights investigation of the shooting.
TheShitBetween: More violence in Ferguson spurred action from Gov. Jay Nixon.

Title: Obama: Eric Holder Heads to Ferguson
Author: Andrew Soergel
ArticleText:
President Barack Obama announced Monday that Attorney General Eric Holder will travel to Ferguson, Missouri, on Wednesday, as the Justice Department and FBI conduct investigations into the killing of unarmed teenager Michael Brown. Brown was shot six times during a confrontation with Ferguson police officer Darren Wilson on Aug. 9.

“The attorney general himself will be traveling to Ferguson on Wednesday to meet with the FBI agents and [Department of Justice] personnel conducting the federal criminal investigation,” Obama said during a news conference. Obama is in Washington briefly from his two-week vacation on Martha's Vineyard in Massachusetts. 

 “[Holder] will also be meeting with other leaders in the community whose support is so critical to bringing about peace and calm in Ferguson,” Obama said.

Missouri Gov. Jay Nixon deployed the National Guard in Ferguson after a weekend of protests turned violent. Despite hopes that the violence had dissipated last week after Missouri State Highway Patrol Capt. Ronald Johnson assumed control of Ferguson’s security efforts from local authorities, tear gas and riot gear returned to the suburb’s streets as riots broke out.


“It’s clear that the vast majority of people are peacefully protesting. What’s also clear is that a small minority of individuals is not,” Obama said. “While I understand the passions and the anger that arise over the death of Michael Brown, giving into that anger by looting or carrying guns, and even attacking the police, only serves to raise tensions and stir chaos.”

Protests, both peaceful and violent, have erupted in Ferguson since Brown’s death. A brief period of calm last week was broken over the weekend, when at least two people were injured in shootings, according to {The Los Angeles Times}<hyperlink=”http://www.latimes.com/nation/nationnow/la-na-nn-ferguson-michael-brown-autopsy-20140818-story.html#page=1”>. Police were also reportedly fired upon.

Obama on Monday urged the Ferguson community to tone down violent protesting to allow justice to run its course. He called on citizens to “build, and not tear down,” to “listen, and not just shout,” and to “seek some understanding, rather than simply holler at each other.”

[tweetbegin 501465461008375808 tweetend] “We’ve got to make sure that we are able to distinguish between peaceful protesters who may have some legitimate grievances, and maybe long-standing grievances, and those who are using this tragic death as an excuse to engage in criminal behavior and tossing Molotov cocktails or looting stores,” Obama said. “They are damaging the cause. They are not advancing it.”

Bubbling racial tension has exacerbated the Ferguson situation. The 53-member Ferguson police force contains only three African-American officers, according to {CBS News}<hyperlink=”http://stlouis.cbslocal.com/2014/08/13/ferguson-mayor-the-african-american-community-has-something-against-law-enforcement-in-many-ways/”>. But about two-thirds of the suburb’s population is African-American, according to {The Wall Street Journal}<hyperlink=”http://www.wsj.com/articles/missouri-governor-deploys-national-guard-after-clashes-in-ferguson-1408348954”>.

Obama on Monday addressed racial inequality in Ferguson and, more broadly, across the U.S. He said anyone those who commit crimes “need to be prosecuted, because every community has an interest in public safety.”

But he said there is a disproportionate number of African-American men brought before the country’s judicial system.

Obama said he thinks part of his job is “to get at those root causes.”

“We can argue about why that happens, because of the poverty they were born into, or the lack of opportunity, or the school systems that failed them, or what have you. But if they commit a crime, then they need to be prosecuted,” Obama said. “Part of that process is also looking at our criminal justice system to make sure that it is upholding the basic principle of: ‘Everybody’s equal before the law.’”

“Where we can make progress in building up more confidence, more trust, making sure that our criminal justice system is acutely aware of the possibilities of disparities in treatment … All those things can make a difference,” he said.
TheShitBetween: The attorney general will visit area torn by racial tension.

Title: Obama Stays Calm in Ferguson Comments
Author: Kenneth T. Walsh
ArticleText:
President Barack Obama is avoiding an emotional response and is taking an even-handed, low-key approach to the racial violence in Ferguson, Missouri.

"It's clear that the vast majority of people are peacefully protesting," Obama said in his lengthiest comments on the tragedy to date. "What's also clear is that a small minority of individuals is not. While I understand the passions and the anger that arise over the death of Michael Brown, giving in to that anger by looting or carrying guns, and even attacking the police, only serves to raise tensions and stir chaos." He called on all sides to "build and not tear down," to "listen and not just shout," and to "seek some understanding rather than simply holler at each other."

The violence was triggered by the shooting of Michael Brown, an unarmed African-American teenager, by white policeman Darren Wilson Aug. 9. Brown was shot six times, and much of the predominantly African-American community of Ferguson is angry that the policeman has not been charged with a crime. Obama is sending Attorney General Eric Holder to Ferguson later this week to help determine what happened and assess how the federal government should respond.

"There are young black men that commit crime," the president told reporters Monday. "We can argue about why that happened--because [of] the poverty they were born into, or the school systems that failed them, or what have you--but if they commit a crime, then they need to be prosecuted, because every community has an interest in public safety."

The latest Pew Research Center poll finds that 65 percent of African-Americans say the police in Ferguson have gone too far in responding to the shooting, while whites are more divided. Thirty-three percent of whites say the police have gone too far; 32 percent say the police response has been about right, while 35 percent give no opinion. Seventy-six percent of blacks have little or no confidence in the official investigations into the shooting, while 52 percent of whites have a great deal or a fair amount of confidence in the investigations, according to the poll.

A year ago, Obama was much more emotional when he reacted to the acquittal of George Zimmerman, a Hispanic neighborhood watch volunteer, in the shooting death of Trayvon Martin, an unarmed black teenager, in Florida. The president said at the time that most African-American men experienced racial profiling--and he was one of them. When Martin was killed in February 2012, Obama also had an emotional reaction, saying, "If I had a son, he'd look like Trayvon....When I think about this boy, I think about my own kids."

Obama has generally been reluctant to publicly discuss racial matters, even though black activists have urged him to speak out more forcefully about the racial discrimination that still exists in the United States. But Obama wants to be known as the president of all Americans, not just the first African American president, White House advisers say. Obama also made these points to me in an interview for my book, "Family of Freedom: Presidents and African Americans in the White House."

And he is being particularly careful in making public assessments of the Michael Brown case because details of what happened remain unclear and because any emotional comments from the president could add to the tensions in the Ferguson area.
TheShitBetween: President appeals to public to eschew violence and remain peaceful.

Title: Ferguson Police Department's Report the Day of Michael Brown's Shooting
Author: Andrew Soergel
ArticleText:
Chaos and confusion consumed Ferguson, Missouri, this week as citizens clashed with riot gear-clad police officers. Capt. Ronald S. Johnson took over Ferguson security efforts Thursday. Riots involving nonlethal bullets, tear gas and smoke bombs have since subsided. But Ferguson residents want answers. They have called for details behind Michael Brown's fatal shooting on Aug. 9, and for the identity of the police officer involved.

On Friday, Ferguson Police Chief Thomas Jackson broke almost a week of police silence. He named Darren Wilson as the officer involved in Brown's shooting.

And Jackson provided a police report that names Brown as a suspect in a convenience store robbery that occurred earlier in the day.
TheShitBetween: Report says Brown was a suspect in earlier incident.

Title: Police Attorneys: Brown Head Wounds Not Fatal to Officer's Defense
Author: Steven Nelson
ArticleText:
Following a week of angry street protests, forensic pathologists working with Michael Brown’s family released independent autopsy results on Monday that show Brown was shot at least six times by Ferguson, Missouri, police officer Darren Wilson.

Lawyers representing the unarmed 18-year-old’s family said at a press conference the results show Wilson unlawfully killed Brown on Aug. 9, and called for the officer’s arrest.

But defense attorneys who have represented police officers in other high-profile shootings of unarmed civilians say the latest findings don’t necessarily doom Wilson.

Pathologists said they found a bullet wound at the apex of the 6-foot-4 Brown’s head and what appeared to be a bullet entry above his right eye that continued downward into his jaw and then shoulder. The wounds appear to show Brown was not standing upright at the time he was shot.

“Just because he was shot somewhere near the top of his head, I don't think that’s indicative of anything at this point," says New Orleans attorney Eric Hessler, who defended officers involved in the 2005 post-Hurricane Katrina shooting deaths of two people on the Danziger Bridge and another person outside a convention center. 

"There are scenarios that I can envision where a police officer would be justified in using deadly force in that situation," Hessler says of the Brown case. “It depends on what the individual was doing while he was shot."

Several officers were convicted of crimes in the post-Katrina cases, but the bridge shooting verdicts were vacated and the case is not resolved.

Attorney James Culleton, who defended New York City police officers who shot and killed unarmed black men Amadou Diallo in 1999 and Sean Bell in 2006, agrees with Hessler that the bullet trajectory isn’t necessarily game-changing.


“If the person is facing you, he’s charging at you, he could have put down his head,” Culleton says. “His head could have just slumped like he was falling forward. It doesn't mean it’s devastating [evidence].”

Diallo, an immigrant from Guinea, was shot at 41 times by four officers who believed his wallet was a gun. Officers fired 50 bullets at Bell when they thought they were in danger. The policemen were found innocent of murder in the Diallo case, and officers in the Bell case were acquitted of manslaughter and other charges.

“The officers reasonably believed in Diallo that he pulled out a gun and in the Sean Bell case that shots were being fired from inside the car,” Culleton says. “You have to believe that deadly force is being used or is about to be used against you.”

Accounts of events leading to Brown's death, which would either confirm or refute Wilson's legal authority to shoot, differ vastly.


Witness Dorian Johnson {says}<hyperlink=”http://www.msnbc.com/msnbc/eyewitness-michael-brown-fatal-shooting-missouri”> Brown was grabbed by the policeman, then fled and ultimately put his hands in the air to surrender before his death. Police, however, say Wilson was attacked while inside his squad car by Brown, who attempted to grab the officer’s gun before a second confrontation outside the car. A woman identifying herself as a friend of the officer {said}<hyperlink=”http://danaloeschradio.com/alleged-friend-of-officer-darren-wilson-offers-his-side/”> Brown then “bum-rushed” Wilson, according to the officer, before the fatal shots. 

“As I understand it there was a violent altercation in the car,” Hessler says. “I’m sure [Wilson] at least experienced some of this individual’s aggression and strength and those are some of the things he had to consider in the second encounter. And one of the things he couldn't consider is simply not engaging him. … If an individual is violently rushing you and you believe that individual if he encounters you can disarm you, you're going to have a problem."

Bullets can be fired very quickly, Culleton says, meaning the number of shots fired at Brown may not be legally significant.

“We had 50 bullets being fired in the Sean Bell case and my client shot 31 times. He actually reloaded his gun. We showed through expert testimony that it took 10 seconds for that to happen,” he says. “When we’re talking five or six shots here, I’m sure that could have happened in a second and a half.”

Hessler, who worked 17 years as a city cop, says, "It’s the officer that shoots once that I have initial suspicion about."

Culleton and Hessler stress that there are many unknown facts, and that it's important to consider further evidence, witness statements and Wilson's account.

"We have numerous cases where police officers have shot unarmed persons and have been found to be completely justified based on the circumstances they believed existed at the time, and it’s the reasonableness of those beliefs that's ultimately going to come into question," Hessler says.

Culleton, whose clients were the subject of media firestorms and protests, says he hopes Ferguson residents will accept the ultimate legal outcome of the Brown case, should it go to trial.

“I would hope that once a jury speaks – or a judge if he's trying the case without a jury – that people accept the verdict because that's what our system’s all about," he says. "I would certainly hope that there would be no more rioting or anything along those lines. “
TheShitBetween: Bullet trajectory and the number of shots fired may not sink the officer who shot the teen, defense attorneys say.

Title: Medical Examiner: Brown Shot Twice in the Head
Author: Andrew Soergel
ArticleText:
Medical examiners hired by Michael Brown’s family attorney said Monday that Brown was shot at least six times – twice in the head – in a conflict August 9 with police officer Darren Wilson in Ferguson, Missouri.

Police forces in Ferguson have kept details of Brown’s shooting under wraps, only on Friday revealing the name of the officer involved in the conflict, despite pleas from Brown's family and the public.

“In a situation like this, facts become very important. Evidence becomes very important. And it is so important that the facts in this case really get out,” attorney Daryl Parks, who is among Brown’s family’s legal team, said during a press conference Monday. “This case has suffered from a lack of transparency.”

A preliminary autopsy released Sunday, independent of one conducted by local authorities, indicates that at least one of the bullets entered the top of Brown’s skull, according to {The New York Times}<hyperlink=”http://www.nytimes.com/2014/08/18/us/michael-brown-autopsy-shows-he-was-shot-at-least-6-times.html”>.

 “Why would he be shot at the very top of his head, a 6-foot-4 man? It makes no sense,” Parks said Monday. “We believe that, given those kinds of facts, this officer should have been arrested.”

Dr. Michael Baden, former New York City chief medical examiner, was hired by Brown’s family lawyer to conduct a private investigation. Baden said the bullet’s trajectory indicates that Brown’s head was bowed when he was shot. 

“It can be because he’s giving up, or because he’s charging forward at the officer,” Baden said of the bullet, according to the Times.

Brown was suspected of stealing a box of cigars from a convenience store at the time of his shooting, according to {The Associated Press}<hyperlink=”http://www.usnews.com/news/us/articles/2014/08/15/turmoil-tear-gas-give-way-to-hope-in-ferguson”>. But Wilson was unaware of that when he first encountered Brown.

Authorities have said that a struggle ensued after Wilson and Brown crossed paths at 12:01 p.m. August 9, according to the AP. But Dorian Johnson, who was reportedly with Brown at the time of the shooting, has said that Brown had his hands raised in the air when he was fired upon. 

Baden said Monday that his preliminary investigation has not found any sign of a struggle between Brown and Wilson.

Brown's family has expressed distrust of how the local authorities have handled the shooting's investigation, after they delayed release of the officer's name and any information surrounding their own autopsy. When authorities did reveal Brown's shooter's name on Friday, they also revealed that Brown was suspected of stealing a box of cigars from a convenience store at the time at released store security footage of the incident. They later revealed Wilson was unaware of that when he first encountered Brown.

Assisting Baden’s investigation is Shawn Parcells, a pathologist assistant based in Kansas, according to {CBS News}<hyperlink=”http://www.cbsnews.com/news/preliminary-autopsy-shows-michael-brown-shot-six-times/”>. Parcells said Monday graze wounds on Brown’s arm indicate that he could have had his hands raised in a defensive posture.

Baden and Parcells found that four bullets entered Brown’s right arm. All had entered from the front and none was reportedly fired at “very close range,” according to the Times.

“People have been asking: ‘How many times was he shot?’ This information could have been released on Day One,” Baden said, according to the Times. “[Local authorities] don’t do that, even as feelings built up among the citizenry that there was a cover-up. We are hoping to alleviate that.”

A third autopsy will be conducted by a federal medical examiner, Attorney General Eric Holder announced Sunday. A department spokesperson said the third examination is a result of “the extraordinary circumstances involved in this case and at the request of the Brown family,” according to the Times.

“The sheer number of bullets and the way they were scattered all over his body showed this police officer had a brazen disregard for the very people he was supposed to protect in that community,” said attorney Benjamin Crump, a member of the Brown family’s legal team, according to the Times. “We want to make sure people understand what this case is about: This case is about a police officer executing a young unarmed man in broad daylight.”

The Ferguson community has been incensed by the shooting and the mystery surrounding it. Looting, riots, fires and violence erupted in the St. Louis suburb as citizens lashed out at law enforcement. Their violence was met with riot gear, tear gas, rubber bullets and smoke bombs.

Gov. Jay Nixon said the atmosphere was “a little bit more like a war zone” before placing Missouri Highway Patrol Capt. Ronald Johnson in charge of Ferguson’s security, according to {The Chicago Tribune }<hyperlink=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/nationworld/chi-missouri-police-shooting-20140813-story.html>.

Johnson initially managed to encourage peaceful protests during the first few days of his appointment.

“We are going to have a different approach and have the approach that we’re in this together,” Johnson said Thursday, according to {CNN}<hyperlink=”http://www.cnn.com/2014/08/14/us/missouri-teen-shooting/”>.

But Ferguson’s peaceful protests dissipated over the weekend, bringing violence, and tear gas, back to the suburb’s streets.

[tweetbegin 501052105214267393 tweetend]At least two people were injured during shootings in Ferguson Sunday night, according to {The Los Angeles Times}<hyperlink=”http://www.latimes.com/nation/nationnow/la-na-nn-ferguson-protest-curfew-20140817-story.html#page=1”>. At least one shooting victim was in critical condition according to {Fox News}<hyperlink=”http://www.foxnews.com/us/2014/08/17/police-try-to-disperse-protesters-defying-ferguson-curfew.html”>.

Nixon on Monday called in the National Guard to help “in restoring peace and order,” according to the {AP}<hyperlink=”https://governor.mo.gov/news/archive/following-coordinated-attacks-civilians-and-law-enforcement-governor-nixon-signs”>.

“Tonight, a day of hope, prayers, and peaceful protests was marred by the violent criminal acts of an organized and growing number of individuals,” Nixon said in a {statement}<hyperlink=”https://governor.mo.gov/news/archive/following-coordinated-attacks-civilians-and-law-enforcement-governor-nixon-signs”> early Monday. “These violent acts are a disservice to the family of Michael Brown and his memory and to the people of this community who yearn for justice to be served and to feel safe in their own homes.”
TheShitBetween: Dr. Michael Baden says Brown was shot 6 times during his encounter with police officer Darren Wilson.

Title: Iraq, Ferguson Chaos Drown Out U.S. Achievement in Syria
Author: Paul D. Shinkman
ArticleText:
President Barack Obama has had little time to celebrate the destruction of some of Syria's most deadly chemical weapons, as spikes in violence both at home and abroad drowned out what the administration has touted as a milestone achievement in regional peace.

A team of engineers and specialists aboard {the Cape Ray}<hyperlink=”http://www.usnews.com/news/articles/2014/01/03/inside-the-ship-that-will-destroy-assads-chemical-weapons”>, a U.S. Maritime Administration industrial ship, completed their weekslong work of neutralizing roughly 600 tons of chemical weapons substances such as mustard gas and a precursor used to make sarin on Monday. The weapons had been on board since early July, following a drawn-out process in which the regime of Syrian President Bashar Assad succumbed to international pressure, rounded up the weapons and shipped them to the Syrian coast through an active war zone.
The White House would likely have been able to spend more time touting the accomplishment if it hadn’t been for growing civil unrest in Ferguson, Missouri, and the fight against the Islamic State group in Iraq – two issues that completely dominated a press conference the president held Monday afternoon.

“This is a major milestone in the international community’s efforts under the leadership of the Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons to rid the Syrian regime of its chemical weapons,” Obama said in a statement late Monday. “It further advances our collective goal to ensure that the Assad regime cannot use its chemical arsenal against the Syrian people and sends a clear message that the use of these abhorrent weapons has consequences and will not be tolerated by the international community.”

Secretary of State John Kerry echoed Obama's sentiments, citing the mid-August 2013 chemical attack blamed on the Assad regime that, according to U.S. estimates, killed more than 1,000 Syrian civilians and kicked off an international initiative to eradicate the weapons.

“The images of children suffering at the hands of a monster’s illicit arsenal reminded all the world why these weapons have long been shunned by the civilized world and revealed for any who still doubted the true face of Assad,” Kerry said in a separate statement.

The OPCW and participating countries, however, must further address discrepancies and omissions related to Assad’s chemical stockpiles and the facilities where they are produced and housed, Kerry said. He cited concerning “reports of systematic use of chlorine gas in opposition areas” by the regime, per a fact-finding mission from the OPCW.

The U.S. will likely have to continue working with Assad despite assertions that he has lost legitimacy as a leader. Following three and a half years of fighting, Assad’s army and increasingly fractured opposition forces have reached a stalemate without any indication the autocrat plans to step down from power.

Obama considered removing Assad’s chemical weapons stores a critical issue last September, when he {called on Congress}<hyperlink=”https://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2013/09/10/remarks-president-address-nation-syria”> to consider a military response if Assad didn’t comply with international pressure to remove the arsenal.

“If we fail to act, the Assad regime will see no reason to stop using chemical weapons,” he said at the time, adding that allowing such attacks could embolden terrorists and later endanger U.S. troops abroad.

“If fighting spills beyond Syria’s borders, these weapons could threaten allies like Turkey, Jordan, and Israel,” Obama said. “And a failure to stand against the use of chemical weapons would weaken prohibitions against other weapons of mass destruction, and embolden Assad’s ally, Iran, which must decide whether to ignore international law by building a nuclear weapon, or to take a more peaceful path.”

The Cape Ray crew had been conducting its sensitive work at sea, reducing the dangerous chemicals into materials no more toxic than common household solvents, Pentagon officials said. The effluent will be disposed of in a landfill in Finland.
TheShitBetween: But even with tons of sarin, VX and mustard gas neutralized, the region seems no more secure.

Title: NAACP to Cops: Identify Michael Brown Shooter
Author: Tierney Sneed
ArticleText:
Vigils, riots and a national debate over alleged police misconduct have marked the three days since Saturday's shooting of an unarmed black teenager by a police officer in a St. Louis suburb. However the details about the incident leading up to Michael Brown’s death in Ferguson, Missouri, remain murky – in part because of a refusal by local authorities to release information, including the name of the officer involved in the shooting.

 “It seems to me that the most important thing here is to let the facts come out as quickly as possible, sending a signal to the community that the investigation is proceeding and that the investigation will in fact be transparent,” says Cornell William Brooks, national president the NAACP. “I don’t believe, where the name will be known at some point, delaying that for any undue period of time helps the situation.”

Ferguson Police Department Chief Thomas Jackson backtracked on an earlier statement that he would release the name once he notified the officer, saying Tuesday the department no longer plans on publicly identifying the shooter.

“The value of releasing the name is far outweighed by the risk of harm to the officer and his family,” Jackson said, {according to The New York Times}<hyperlink=”http://www.nytimes.com/2014/08/13/us/ferguson-police-cite-safety-risk-in-decision-not-to-name-officer-in-shooting.html?smid=tw-share”>, referring to threats made against the police on social media. Anti-police rhetoric has undergirded many of the protests following Brown’s death. Furthermore, the group of web hackers known as Anonymous have even threatened to hack into the police department website and make public private information about the officers and their families.

But activists argue that authorities’ reluctance to give more details about their investigations is making the situation worse, not better, as the uproar over Brown's death – a culmination of long-standing tensions between the largely white police force and the majority black Ferguson community – continues.

“The police department owes a duty of safety to the police officer, but there is a duty owed to the community in terms of the accountability,” Brooks, who has been on the ground in Ferguson, says. “It’s safe to say that people are unsatisfied with their response so far.”

Even before the shooting, there had been concerns raised over how police officers interact Ferguson residents. {As The Washington Post reported}<hyperlink=”https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/post-nation/wp/2014/08/12/the-breaking-point-for-ferguson/”>, a disproportionate number of black drivers are pulled over and arrested in the area, and researchers at University of California at Los Angeles are studying the St. Louis County Police Department's policing protocols. In January, the Missouri chapter of {NAACP filed}<hyperlink=”http://www.stltoday.com/news/local/crime-and-courts/naacp-files-civil-rights-complaint-against-st-louis-county-police/article_5e3ddfee-b883-55a1-bf08-948f74c96e47.html”> a civil-rights complaint alleging that county officers engaged in racial profiling in stores in the St. Louis area.

The Justice Department, working with the FBI, has launched a supplementary, concurrent inquiry into the Brown's death, per {a statement from Attorney General Eric Holder}<hyperlink=”http://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/statement-attorney-general-holder-recent-shooting-incident-ferguson-missouri”>. Meanwhile, politicians like Missouri {Gov. Jay Nixon}<hyperlink=”https://governor.mo.gov/news/archive/gov-nixon-asks-us-department-justice-independent-investigation-fatal-shooting-ferguson”>​ and {Sen. Claire McCaskill, D-Mo. }<hyperlink=”http://www.mccaskill.senate.gov/media-center/news-releases/mccaskill-statement-on-ferguson-shooting”>, and {Sen. Roy Blunt, R-Mo. }<hyperlink=”http://www.blunt.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/news?ID=f98d3621-60d3-4cd8-9522-63b7d8e6d4a1”>, ​ issued statements echoing calls for transparency in investigations. Rep. John Conyers, D-Mich., Rep. Marcia Fudge, D-Ohio, and Rep. Lacy Clay, D-Mo., ​ all members of the Congressional Black Caucus, also {sent a letter}<hyperlink=”http://cbc.fudge.house.gov/uploads/Letter-8.11.14-%20DOJ%20Inquiry%20Into%20Michael%20Brown%20Death%20(1).pdf”> to Holder calling for an expanded look into a suggested pattern of civil rights abuses by Ferguson officers, independent of the St. Louis County’s Police Department investigation into Brown's shooting.

“To the extent that this latest episode around unjustified use of force is one in a series of concerns raised by the NAACP and others, the scope of the investigation should include Michael Brown and other civil rights violations that may be found,” NAACP’s Brooks says.

President Barack Obama broke his silence on the matter with a {statement}<hyperlink=”http://www.ky3.com/news/local/president-obama-issues-statement-on-death-of-ferguson-missouri-teenager/21048998_27431674”> released Tuesday afternoon.

“The death of Michael Brown is heartbreaking, and Michelle and I send our deepest condolences to his family and his community at this very difficult time," he said. " As Attorney General Holder has indicated, the Department of Justice is investigating the situation along with local officials, and they will continue to direct resources to the case as needed."
TheShitBetween: Lawmakers, activists call for more transparent investigation into shooting of the unarmed black teen.

Title: Americans Divided on Whether Brown Shooting Raises Race Issues
Author: Tierney Sneed
ArticleText:
It’s not just Ferguson, Missouri – the site of more than a week of intense and sometimes violent protests – that is divided over the death of Michael Brown, an unarmed black teenager who was shot by local white police officer Darren Wilson Aug. 9. The American public at large is split in their opinions of the shooting and its aftermath, {a survey released Monday by the Pew Research Center finds}<hyperlink=”http://www.people-press.org/2014/08/18/stark-racial-divisions-in-reactions-to-ferguson-police-shooting/”>, with responses largely falling along racial lines.

Americans are in disagreement – 44 percent to 40 percent – as to whether the case raises important issues about race or if race is getting too much attention. When those responses were broken down by respondents' race, 80 percent of the African-Americans said race was an issue to be raised, while only 37 percent of whites felt this way. Meanwhile, 47 percent of whites surveyed said race is getting more attention than it deserves in light of the shooting.

Furthermore, when asked about the police response to the shooting – which {has featured the use of military tactics}<hyperlink=”http://www.usnews.com/news/articles/2014/08/14/ferguson-and-the-shocking-nature-of-us-police-militarization”> to face off with protesters, who have occasionally turned to looting or violence – 65 percent of blacks said the police in Ferguson have gone too far, compared to 33 percent whites.

Likewise, black respondents showed far less confidence in the police’s ability to investigate the shooting. More than three-fourths, or 76 percent, of African-Americans said they have not much or no confidence in the ongoing investigation. A majority of the whites surveyed, 52 percent, said they had a fair to great amount of confidence in the police’s investigation.

The way opinions about Brown’s shooting differ according to one’s race was already evident anecdotally {in reports}<hyperlink=”http://www.buzzfeed.com/joelanderson/is-race-an-issue-in-ferguson-depends-on-who-you-ask#.vy1V5V7wE”> coming out of the St. Louis area, as well as in the largely-white group of demonstrators {who turned out near a local St. Louis TV station}<hyperlink=”http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/08/17/darren-wilson-protest_n_5686491.html”> Sunday in support of Wilson and the police. St. Louis {is the ninth most}<hyperlink=”http://www.motherjones.com/politics/2014/08/10-insane-numbers-ferguson-killing”> segregated metro area in America, according to {a Brown University study}<hyperlink=”http://www.s4.brown.edu/us2010/Data/Report/report2.pdf”>. St. Louis County {is 70 percent white}<hyperlink=”http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2014/08/18/ferguson-and-the-urban-suburban-race-war.html”>, while about two-thirds of Ferguson’s residents are black. Its police force however is almost entirely white, as are many of its government officials. {Some}<hyperlink=”http://www.usnews.com/news/articles/2014/08/12/naacp-to-cops-identify-michael-brown-shooter”> say this division has created long-simmering {tensions}<hyperlink=”http://www.usnews.com/news/articles/2014/08/14/michael-brown-eric-garner-deaths-add-scrutiny-to-broken-windows-policing”> between the community and authorities, which was turned up to full boil by Brown’s death.

While the gap between black and white opinions regarding the role of race in the events in Ferguson is apparent in the Pew poll, the survey also noted whites are more likely to see race as a factor in Brown’s shooting than in the shooting of Trayvon Martin. In a 2013 survey, only 28 percent of whites said that Martin’s case raised important issues about race. Martin was an unarmed teenager shot and killed by a neighborhood watchman in Florida in 2012.
TheShitBetween: More whites, however, see Ferguson as a racial issue, than they did the Trayvon Martin case in 2013.

Title: Obama Asks Cops to Lay Off Reporters; Advocates Ask Same of Him
Author: Steven Nelson
ArticleText:
President Barack Obama and Attorney General Eric Holder asked police on Thursday not to jail reporters doing their jobs in Missouri as press advocates asked them not to jail Pulitzer Prize-winning reporter James Risen for doing his job.

“Here in the United States of America, police should not be bullying or arresting journalists who are just trying to do their jobs and report to the American people on what they see on the ground,” Obama said in a televised press conference around noon.

“Journalists must not be harassed or prevented from covering a story that needs to be told,” Holder added in a statement.

On Wednesday, reporters from The Huffington Post and The Washington Post were arrested inside a McDonald’s restaurant while covering protests against the Saturday shooting death of Michael Brown, 18, by police in Ferguson, Missouri. They were released without charges.

Ironically, a large coalition of press freedom organizations gathered at about the same time as Obama’s statement for a preplanned National Press Club rally asking the Obama administration to drop its pursuit of Risen’s testimony about a confidential source.

Risen says he would rather go to jail than comply. The fight has dragged on for years, and in June the Supreme Court {declined}<hyperlink=”http://www.usnews.com/news/articles/2014/06/02/james-risen-supreme-court-reporters-privilege-case”> to hear an appeal from Risen’s lawyers seeking a constitutional or common law reporter's privilege.

Obama’s request that police in Missouri not harass reporters “certainly is hypocritical,” vintage TV personality Phil Donahue, who appeared on a panel of Risen supporters, tells U.S. News.

 “It’s very bewildering,” Donahue says. “I just don’t get it, especially from a constitutional lawyer.”

Representatives of the Freedom of the Press Foundation, Reporters Without Borders, the Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press, the Government Accountability Project and the Committee to Protect Journalists took turns asking Holder and Obama to back off Risen.

“The Democratic Party has given hope a bad name,” said RootsAction co-founder Norman Solomon, whose group delivered to the Department of Justice a pro-Risen petition with more than 125,000 signatures. “This is inherently a political case.”

Risen said he was grateful for the support and said Holder and Obama “turned this [case] into a showdown over the First Amendment.”

The award-winning New York Times reporter said the roughing up of journalists by Missouri cops was part of a larger post-9/11 struggle confronting reporters. “It’s all part of the same issue,” he said.

Federal prosecutors want Risen to testify at the trial of Jeffrey Sterling, a former CIA employee who allegedly informed Risen about an embarrassingly mismanaged operation to supply Iran with flawed nuclear weapon designs. 

The CIA operation – detailed in Risen's 2006 book, "State of War: The Secret History of the CIA and the Bush Administration" – fell apart when the Russian scientist hired to deliver the bomb blueprints noticed the flaws and tipped off the Iranians.

It’s unclear what the Department of Justice has in mind for Risen. Earlier this year, Holder and one of his deputies hinted they would not seek jail time, but they have not explicitly ruled out the option.
TheShitBetween: Press activists rally against the possible jailing of a Pulitzer Prize winner.

Title: Use of SWAT Teams Affects Minorities More
Author: Lindsey Cook
ArticleText:
The world watched Ferguson, Missouri, the last week as police dressed in riot gear with military tanks met protesters in the street. The protests followed the shooting of an unarmed black teenager, Michael Brown, who was killed by a white police officer on Aug. 9.

The racial tensions in the community are bubbling up after years of misunderstanding and lack of respect between the community and the police. The Ferguson Police Department and the St. Louis County Department, the unit in charge of the investigation, both have a history of racial profiling (like many police units in the United States).

The police obtained the military-type equipment used on protesters through the {Department of Defense's 1033 Program}<hyperlink=”http://dps.mo.gov/dir/programs/cjle/dod.asp”>. The program provides surplus military equipment to state and local law enforcement agencies. The equipment is often used in SWAT (Special Weapons and Tactics) teams. Originally meant to be used in hostage situations, terrorists attacks, active shooter situations and other extreme circumstances, the SWAT teams now use the equipment largely for "no knock" search warrants, often those concerning a small amount of drugs. Race appears to be a factor in the deployment of SWAT teams, according to a report from the {American Civil Liberties Union}<hyperlink=”https://www.aclu.org/”>.

For the report, the ACLU sent records requests to 260 law enforcement agencies for incident reports and all other records documenting the deployment of SWAT teams in 2011 and 2012. The researchers received 3,844 records in response to their requests for use in the report.

SWAT team deployment for hostage, barricade or active shooter situations only accounted for 7 percent of cases studied. The vast majority of cases, 79 percent, were for a search of someone's home, mostly for low-level drug investigations.


SWAT teams are often used to carry out the war on drugs, which {past research}<hyperlink=”https://www.aclu.org/files/FilesPDFs/ACF4F34.pdf”> has shown affects blacks more. Even though blacks and whites use marijuana at roughly the same rates, black Americans are four times more likely to be arrested on a possession charge than their white counterparts, according to {The New York Times}<hyperlink=”http://www.nytimes.com/2013/06/04/us/marijuana-arrests-four-times-as-likely-for-blacks.html?_r=0”>.

SWAT teams were more likely to be deployed on blacks and Latinos than on whites according to the report. Often, these SWAT encounters use excessive violence, knocking down doors with battering rams, throwing flashbang grenades and sometimes injuring the people inside, shooting their dogs or destroying property.

The deployments are supposed to be for "high-risk" situations, but there aren't comprehensive guidelines for what constitutes "high-risk." The ACLU found that both the danger and the search results are often overestimated by police before they bust down doors.
TheShitBetween: A report from the ACLU shows blacks come into contact with police militarization more than whites.

Title: Press Not Targeted in Tear Gas Attack, Missouri Sheriff's Spokesman Says
Author: Steven Nelson
ArticleText:
A TV crew reporting on protests near St. Louis was tear-gassed Wednesday evening, but a law enforcement spokesman says the incident was not an intentional attack on the press.

In fact, Lt. David Tiefenbrunn of the St. Charles County Sheriff’s Department tells U.S. News members of his department actually rescued the crew from a dangerous situation.

Footage posted online Thursday shows reporters from Al Jazeera America on a dark street fleeing as a cloud of tear gas envelops their camera and lighting gear.

A tactical SWAT vehicle from the St. Charles County Sheriff’s Department is seen driving up to the crew's equipment after the reporters fled, with law enforcement officers then lowering cameras and lights.

The footage made headlines shortly after news that two reporters, Wesley Lowery of The Washington Post and Ryan Reilly of The Huffington Post, were arrested inside a McDonald’s restaurant and detained Wednesday while covering protests against the Saturday shooting of 18-year-old Michael Brown by a police officer in Ferguson, Missouri. Lowery and Reilly were released without charges.

In a Thursday {statement}<hyperlink=”http://america.aljazeera.com/tools/pressreleases/statement.html”>, Al Jazeera America President Kate O’Brian called the tear gas incident an “egregious assault on freedom of the press that was clearly intended to have a chilling effect on our ability to cover this important story.”

“They were easily identifiable as a working television crew,” O’Brian said. “As they were setting up their camera for a live report, tear gas canisters landed in their proximity and police fired rubber bullets in their direction. Police continued to shoot after crew members clearly and repeatedly shouted ‘Press.'”

Tiefenbrunn, who spoke with members of the SWAT team that responded after the crew was gassed, says that’s not what happened.


“From my understanding, there was crowds in the area, approaching the area, and that's why the tear gas was deployed – to keep the area clear,” he says. “We were responding up that street because there was some bright lights that were being lit up on the officers and was causing them not to be able to see up the street to see if there was a disturbance going on.”

Tiefenbrunn says officers weren't aware the lights were from a TV crew when the gas was fired and calls descriptions of the incident being an attack on the press "totally incorrect."

The four members of the Al Jazeera crew were collected by members of his department, taken to their gear and then taken to safety, Tiefenbrunn says. “They took it as more of a rescue as opposed to what was portrayed on [TV], that we were actually firing tear gas at the media."

The spokesman says his department didn't fire the tear gas and that he's not sure who did.

“I have no idea, there are so many agencies out there, with the noise and things that go on out there it’s hard to keep track of who’s firing what and where the orders are coming from,” he says. 

A statement provided to U.S. News by a member of the Al Jazeera America crew – via spokeswoman Jocelyn Austin – confirms uncertainty about who fired the tear gas and the warm feelings the crew felt for the responding SWAT team.

“There were multiple police departments involved in this whole incident,” the member of the crew said. “One of these departments, finding out our team’s predicament, came to our aid.”
TheShitBetween: Al Jazeera America's boss was outraged, but a police spokesman says the crew 'took it as more of a rescue.'

Title: 4 Questions About the Army National Guard, Answered by Graphs
Author: Lindsey Cook
ArticleText:
The city of Ferguson, Missouri, has suffered almost nightly chaos since the fatal shooting of an unarmed black teenager on Aug. 9. 

Locals and transplants alike have taken to the streets to protest the killing of {Michael Brown, 18}<hyperlink=”http://www.usnews.com/news/us/articles/2014/08/18/governor-nixon-orders-national-guard-to-ferguson?int=9a5208”>. Again, last night, a militarized police in SWAT gear and armed with tear gas met the crowd after violence broke out. Missouri Gov. Jay Nixon signed an {executive order}<hyperlink=”http://www.usnews.com/news/blogs/data-mine/2014/08/12/obamas-executive-orders-not-so-bad-when-compared-to-states”> calling in the National Guard to assist with keeping peace during tonight's demonstrations. Last week, Nixon put the Missouri Highway Patrol in charge. He has also cancelled the midnight curfew that was in place last night.

The National Guard is composed of part-time military members in each state and the U.S. territories of Guam, the Virgin Island and Puerto Rico. When not under federal control, National Guard units are deployed at the command of the state governor. The National Guard assisted after Hurricane Katrina in 2005.

Who makes up the National Guard?

The Guard's racial make-up is close to that of the United States, as a whole. According to {Census QuickFacts}<hyperlink=”http://quickfacts.census.gov/qfd/states/00000.html”>, 77.7 percent of the U.S. population identify as white, 13.2 percent as black or African American, 1.2 percent as American Indian or Alaska Native, 5.3 percent as Asian. 
What does the National Guard do?
The National Guard can be deployed overseas or domestically. The Missouri National Guard has supported state emergency missions such as flooding in eastern Missouri, flash floods in central Missouri and wildfires in Colorado. 

How much does it cost to run the National Guard?The Missouri National Guard has $391,785,888 in funding, {according to a report for fiscal year 2013}<hyperlink=”http://www.arng.army.mil/News/publications/AfinancialReports/2013/FY13%20ARNG%20AFR.pdf”>.
TheShitBetween: As protests over the police killing of Michael Brown continue in the ninth day, the Missouri governor has called in the National Guard.

Title: Obama Returns to Washington
Author: Kenneth T. Walsh
ArticleText:
President Obama is back in Washington, searching for answers.

He returned to the White House from his vacation Sunday night, and his schedule Monday calls for meetings with advisers including Vice President Joe Biden to discuss the crisis in Iraq. U.S. air strikes are helping Iraqi government forces in their battle against Islamic extremists, and Obama is being criticized for contradictory reasons, both for not acting aggressively enough in Iraq and for apparently allowing the original limited mission to expand.

He also will meet Monday with Attorney General Eric Holder to discuss the crisis in Ferguson, Missouri. Violence has erupted there repeatedly as African-Americans protest the killing of unarmed black teen Michael Brown by police Aug. 9.

To attend the meetings in Washington, Obama broke away from his vacation at Martha's Vineyard, Massachusetts, where he had spent a week playing golf and relaxing with his family. He also received regular briefings on the various crises that have become flashpoints in recent weeks.

He is scheduled to resume his vacation Tuesday and stay at Martha's Vineyard through the weekend.

Other possible matters for discussion in Washington are the crisis in Ukraine, the fighting in Gaza, ways to overhaul the immigration system, and the humanitarian crisis precipitated by the arrival of thousands of unaccompanied children who have crossed the U.S. border with Mexico.

Obama's back-and-forth schedule illustrates a fundamental truth about presidential vacations: Commanders in chief must deal with crises as they erupt, and they can never fully break away from their duties.
TheShitBetween: President halts vacation to address multiple crises.
